Port Arthur, Ont.,
October 7, 1941.

Attention-Supt. of Welfare & Training

Sir:

I beg to refer you to my letter of October 6th, with regard to flood water in the Gull Bay school, and have to advise that the basement of the Mobert school is in a similar condition.

It will be necessary to put men to work immediately and I have estimated the cost very roughly at $40.00. Would you kindly authorize this work as soon as possible and forward a cheque for this amount to cover labour.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, October 11, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th instant and to state that you are authorized to take whatever steps may be necessary for the removal of the water from the basement of the Mobert School.

It is noted that the cost of removing this water will amount to approximately $40. In view of the fact that no amount was placed in the estimates to meet this emergency, it would be appreciated if you would keep the cost down to the lowest possible figure.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Mr. J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Attention—Supt. of Welfare & Training

Dear Sir:

A case of typhoid developed at the Mobert reservation recently and immediate steps were taken to prevent an epidemic. Samples of the water were taken and tested and found to be unfit for use. This being the likely source of infection it was urgently requested by the Ontario Department of Health that a new source of water supply be installed immediately and on the recommendation of Dr. J. C. Gillie and Dr. G. W. Houston, a pump and point etc. was purchased and shipped to the Mobert reserve, and arrangements made for the immediate installation of same.

The pump was purchased from the Coslett Machinery and Equipment Co. of Fort William, the only immediate source of supply at that time, at a cost of $27.85.

I trust my action in this matter meets with the Department's approval and I would be pleased to receive authority to pass this account on to Ottawa for payment.

Yours truly,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Br., Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

It is necessary for me to advise the occurrence of a small fire recently in the kitchen of the Mobert Indian day school.

To make a few minor repairs to the woodwork and do some painting and kalsomining it will be necessary to expend the sum of approximately $45.00. Would you therefore kindly advise if authority may be granted to proceed with work in this connection.

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.
Ottawa, May 10, 1945.

Mr. J. G. Burk, Indian Agent, Port Arthur, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 4th instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $45.00 to cover repairs and painting in the teacher's living quarters at the Mobert Indian Day School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Referring to minor repairs required at the Mobert Indian Day School, I wish to report that I have just received a letter from our Teacher, Mr. J.R. Douglas, informing me that he was unable to communicate with this Office sooner as he broke his ankle shortly after the summer holidays started.

Mr. Douglas informs me that it will be necessary to kalsomine the school-room, scrape the floors, putty the windows, and repair storm windows, etc. The approximate cost, including 16 pkgs. of muresco, labour, etc. will be $50.00.

I have been informed that the teacher will be able to complete this work after school hours, and I would be pleased to receive the necessary authorization to have this work done.

J.G. Burk, Indian Agent,
Port Arthur Agency.
Ottawa, 14th September, 1945.

Mr. J.G. Burk, Indian Agent, Port Arthur, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 10th instant, you may expend an amount of $50.00 in materials and labour in redecorating the Mobert Indian Day School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Res., Ottawa, Ont.

Attention: School Branch

Referring to our verbal conversation during my last visit to Ottawa, in connection with repairs to the Robert Indian Day School, as you will no doubt recall, I mentioned this school is situated 33 miles west of White River and it is very hard to heat. The building is situated on top of a hill, and unfortunately, it has not been lined with rock wool. Consequently, it is extremely cold.

In order to make this building warm and comfortable, it will be necessary to line it with rock wool and insul brick siding. The cost of this material as per account enclosed herewith is $318.45. It will also be necessary to purchase linoleum for the kitchen which will cost approximately $30.00. I would also recommend the purchase of paint, varnish, oils, axe, saw frame etc., which I have listed and which will amount to approximately $36.28.

On my recent visit to this school, I found that the cess pool which the kitchen water drains into, will have to be rebuilt and dug-out, and this will cost approximately $25.00. There are minor repairs in connection with the rebuilding of the porch steps, putty windows etc., including repairing crack in the basement wall. The chimney is also badly in need of repairs and will cost approximately $75.00 to tear it down and rebuild. The approximate cost of labour in connection with putting on the brick siding, rock wool and rebuilding chimney etc., at $.68¢ per hour, would be approximately $200.00.

I would be pleased to receive the necessary authorization to start this work immediately.

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Port Arthur, Ontario,
2nd October, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Res.
Attention: Mr. P. Phelan

No doubt you will recall, on my last visit we discussed the building of two schools, one at Mission Road, and one at Lake Helen. Unfortunately, material and supplies cannot be purchased for these two schools and consequently, we will have to wait until next year.

However, I have just received a phone call from the Fairbanks-Morse, who assured me that the oil heaters I ordered for the Mobert Indian Day School, should reach Port Arthur not later than the 15th of this month. He said that he would set aside two for the Pic School and two for the Mobert School. The approximate amount of oil which I presume each school would use would be ten barrels. It will cost approximately .17¢ per gallon, f.o.b. Schreiber, so the cost of the heating will be just about on a par with fuel wood, which is so hard to get. I was looking through my files but cannot find any letter from you authorizing the purchase of the oil heaters.

If our funds are getting low, we could eliminate the two heaters for the Pic Indian Day School. Fairbanks-Morse advise they will let me know the approximate cost very shortly. I believe the stoves will cost in the neighbourhood of $75.00 each. This price, of course, includes a reduction of 25% on cost price. Fairbanks-Morse promised to let me know the exact cost in a few days and I will drop you another line. I thought possibly I should write direct to you, as I had taken the matter up with you personally.

I do hope I will be able to get down sometime later this fall and have a good long talk with you, as there are many things I would like to discuss. With very kind personal regards,

Yours sincerely,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter received here from Mr. J.R. Douglas, teacher of our Mobert Indian Day School; this letter is self-explanatory.

April 12, 1947.

Mr. J.G. Burk,
Indian Agent,
Fort Arthur, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Pursuant to our recent conversation regarding the painting of the school; I wish to advise that the eaves trimming and porches, etc. need going over with white paint to brighten up the building. The porch floors need to be given two coats of gray paint.

I have the paint on hand at present to do this work. However, I would estimate I would need about a $100. grant for this for labour purposes, and for the under-mentioned. (It is slow work doing these windows, frames, etc.

The bed-room and living room require re-finish-ing also. For this purpose, I would require the following:

6 pkgs. Muresco (Ivory),
4 pkgs. Muresco, (Sea Green).

We wish to decorate the kitchen also, but have sufficient paints, etc. from last time to do this job.

Yours very truly,

sgd--J.R. Douglas.

J.R. Douglas.

Mobert Indian Day School

We are in receipt of a demand for various items for the Mobert Indian Day School, as per the attached requisition. We have instructed the teacher that in the case of the two pair of sheets, that she will be obliged to personally make this purchase since the Department do not assume responsibility for purchase of bedding.

Mrs. MacNeil has also requested authority to purchase a $9.00 tea set, same to be used for visits of missionaries, school inspectors or various other officials. She also requested authority to purchase a lounge chair for the living room at a cost approximating $49.00, but has agreed to meet half the cost of this purchase from her personal funds.

Mrs. MacNeil has made the request that the school be supplied with a water pipe line and we are investigating the feasibility of such a project. A request of a similar nature is the construction of a picket fence around the school. We have instructed a capable Indian carpenter on the Reserve to consult with her and he is to submit to us an estimate of the cost. Upon receipt of this estimate we will communicate with you further.

Another item Mrs. MacNeil has requested is the painting and kalsomining of the residence and for this she estimates $20.00 will be expended in wages and $10.00 for paints and kalsomine.

It may be stated, in conclusion, that Mrs. MacNeil appears to be none too happy regarding her posting to the Mobert School. She constantly remarks about the Shubenacadie School in a nostalgic manner, impressing upon us the fact that this school had running water, electricity and modern in all respects. These comments are made notwithstanding the fact that the Mobert Indian Day School is in first class state of repairs.
though it may be admitted that some kalsomining could be done of course, there is no electricity nor running water. It is wondered if she had been apprised of these latter two deficiencies prior to her accepting the appointment. Another point raised by Mrs. MacNeil is the fact that the caretaker of the Shubenacadie School was paid at the rate of $65.00 per month for services. She is considerably disturbed at the payment of only $5.00 per month for caretaking duties at Mobert, stating that the discrepancy is too great, considering Shubenacadie is only a two-room school. Unquestionably, we shall have to have your consideration to pay the caretaker of the Mobert School an amount of $15.00 to $20.00 monthly. The amount of $5.00 monthly paid in the past was satisfactory to Mr. Douglas while teaching, for he was not adverse to undertaking a large share of the caretaking duties himself such as shovelling snow, bringing in water and wood, putting on storm windows, etc., and these duties cannot be undertaken by Mrs. MacNeil, who appears to be in rather fragile health.

We trust that the morale of Mobert Reserve will not deteriorate in any respect through the presence of Mrs. MacNeil for it appears that she is commenting to the Reserve Indians about the fine homes in Shubenacadie with light and water. As you know, no such centralization programme is in effect in Ontario (insofar as I know) and I do not consider it very judicious for one to come from one Reserve to another, to make remarks of a deprecating nature, for it is bound to cause a certain amount of dissention.

Your authority to make the purchases as requested and also for the increase of caretaker's wages to an amount as stated, will be welcomed, please.

Yours very truly,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, October 12, 1916.

Rev. Sir,

Application having been made to the Department for the establishment of a school for the benefit of certain Indians that are located near the Tadanac Club property in the township of Freeman, a little inland from Partridge Bay, inquiries were made and it is found that there are some ten children of school age living there and the Department has been advised that a building could be obtained which would answer for school purposes temporarily.

Before deciding on any definite action in regard to this proposition the Department would be pleased to learn from you, as you are in the best position to furnish the desired information, whether you think there would be a sufficient attendance of children to justify the establishment of a school there. If so, kindly state what accommodation could be found for a teacher and whether you know of a suitable person to take charge of this school, if established. Mr. Joseph Partridge, at present temporarily in charge of the Henvey Inlet school, might be asked whether he would be willing to take charge of this school, as the Department is to put a qualified white teacher at Henvey Inlet. If your answer is favourable the Department would be disposed to give a school at this point a trial.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. David Menomance,
Parry Island Reserve,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Dear Sir,

The Hon. Wallace Nesbitt has spoken to me several times about setting apart a reserve for certain Indians who are living near the property of the Tadanac Club.

I was assured that you would take an interest in this matter, as you knew something of the circumstances.

We would be willing to establish a school for these Indians and I have that matter now under consideration. I think it would be advisable to give them a small reserve. Would you kindly take this matter up with the Minister of Lands & Forests?

Dear Miss Tobey:

Sir - I beg to ask you a few questions in regard to our teacher and the school here. First I want to relate that my two girls Kate and Alice had been attending school all winter and proved themselves to be quite intelligent and ready to learn, but during their attendance in this school I always took particular notice as to their slowness in their efforts to reach their expected promotion until they were somewhat tired and discouraged, for in fact, they had studied hard enough to deserve credit of promotion.

And three weeks ago I placed Alice at Barry Island Indian School and after a full week's attendance she was placed or promoted to another class.
And on inquiring here how her fellow pupils are getting along, I am informed that they are still hitched to the same class, proving therefore, that the school and the teacher mainly, are very unsatisfactory to me.

First I beg to ask, are you going or intending to place that same teacher for the next term? If so let us know, for there are the majority of us who do not appreciate her services.

Does the Indian Department intend to purchase our house for school purposes?

If so, let me know before the first of next month as I intend to move in there soon. We do not gain anything on our house being used as governmental property, or public use. If Joe Sandy had tried to say anything to you when you passed here last in regard to our public affairs and the school I beg to say that it is all lie. Furthermore I beg to inform you to never ask Joe Sandy any question in regard to our affairs in our settlement.
Anything in particular that you wish to know that regards the welfare of our Indian folks. Please write to our own address.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Recently returned from my visit and received your letter dated Sept., the 12th. I have made the arrangements to carry on the Evangelistic work among the different reserves lying near by where my services may be called for; beside that I have enrolled two or three courses of study by correspondence that will keep me busy for the coming months.

School teaching is a nice work I can recollect very well the time when I was sent to Henvey Inlet to teach there in 1888-1889. by permission of the school Inspector Rev. Geo. Grant, and Dr. Thom. Walton who was visiting Indian Superintendent at that time. I don't think would be a wise thing to do to change my plan of work after making known to my intentions to the public. Mr. Scott just the very thing I am taking now to prepare myself so I can be a teacher and preach as well should I go back in the active work in the future where the mission is connected with a school. As I am left without a station at my own request, I like to be near where I can get an assistance by the school teachers for the courses that I have enrolled. Moose Deer Point is out of the way who is taking this kind of study. Moose Deer Point is located about midway between Parry Sound and Penetanguishene, that is, about thirty miles each way and to the railroad of C.P.R. almost twenty miles walk. I trust that a year from now will be well prepared to take charge of any school under Mr. Logan's superintendency like Henvey Inlet school because its near the railroad and easy to get down to town.

Yours very truly,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo, containing a report on your visit to the Moose Deer Point Indian Day School, and stating the condition of the building and the repairs and alterations required.

You should draw the attention of the Department to the repairs and alterations required, at a time, next spring, when you will be in a position to attend to the purchase of the material required and have the work done. Dear Sir,

On June 24th I went with Mr. Daly to Monk Point to inspect the Indian children. I saw all the school children and then visited the homes, where I examined the children under school age. The king children referred to in your letter are not on the reserve, but I presume they belong to Christian Island. Among the children I saw no case of goiter nor did I see any marked case or noticeable one among the adults.

One married woman told me she had had an enlarged thyroid, but that it had "gone away."

One little lad from Fairy Island had tubercular glands; another had had very much enlarged cervical glands. Some of the people needed medical attention, but none were near in a condition to cause any alarm.

Since my visit, I have had in the hospital a Mrs. Williams from Moose Point, who was suffering from symptoms of the knee joint and who no doubt was and is tuberculous.

On the whole I would say that the health of the people of Moose Point was better than the health of those at Parry Island, Shesawaga or Beaurivage.

Among the Indians on all the reserves, scrofula, (chronic tuberculosis) evidenced by enlarged or broken down glands, is very common; skin diseases are also very prevalent, and there is some gouty but not as much, I venture to say as there is among the white people in Parry Sound or in many places along the Great Lakes.

If you think it wise I could make monthly visits to Moose Point in the summertime, going down first on the Midland City boat, it is running.

I have made two visits to Moose Point in all, one in 1925 to vaccinate the children and one in June 1926 to report on the gouty situation.

Yours truly,

However, if it is the wish of the Department to send this young man here, I shall be pleased to do all I can to assist him and explain to him what is required in this school.

Dear Dr. McGill:

I have been approached through several of the adult Indians in regard to the school question at Moose Point Reservation. I understand that representations are being made to close this school on account of lack of attendance. I hesitate to write the following in anything but a desire to see this small band whom my father was so interested in, have anything but the best considered acts done on their behalf.

The teacher who was there last year was, I think, unsuitable and on his account to some degrees the attendance fell off considerably. After a very careful check, I find that there are 14 children anxious and ready to receive tuition. In addition to this, I think given the proper teacher, several of the older ones who have already attended, would return with little pressing, partly owing to lack of other employment and partly through a degree of interest in the benefits they have already received.

The small band, I know you will agree, are at present reflecting the past years of the school's existence since it was started by Dr. Scott at the instigation of my father and it would be a pity to allow this to be dropped when the material, i.e., buildings, are there already and the actual teacher's remuneration is the only required outlay.

Again let me add that I am writing in an endeavour to see that you receive as accurate an impression of conditions in that locality as possible and not in a spirit of interference, but I would suggest that if possible, you might secure the services for that position of the former teacher, Miss Donald, who made a very real impression on the children but left for a period of further study. I understand that Miss Donald is available and would accept this position if it were offered.

Please excuse my having bothered you with this problem, but every time, I have been at our house near the Village, I have representations made to me to use my influence in bringing the subject to your attention.

Trusting that I may have the pleasure of calling on you when I am in Ottawa next.

Yours sincerely,

W. R. Nesbitt

Dear Mr. Nesbitt:

I have now received a report from our departmental officers regarding educational facilities for the Indians of the Moose Point Band.

I am advised that there is a school building at Moose Point which was erected some forty-five years ago. It belongs to the Band and is now used as a dwelling by the Chief. This school was operated by the Branch until several years ago when because of disrepair and the difficulty of obtaining teachers it was closed.

Due to no school facilities being available, the non-Indians who had sent their children to the Indian school made representations to the Provincial Government and a small provincial school was erected less than ten years ago. This is known as "Twelve Mile Bay School". It is a well constructed building, well equipped, good lighting, good blackboard space and inside toilets. At the present time, there is only one non-Indian attending this school. The remainder are Indian pupils and their tuition is paid for by this Department. Due to taxation of the numerous rather expensive summer homes in the area, the school finances are in very good shape and they are not dependent on the grant received from the Department for the Indian children in attendance. However, if the Indian children did not attend this school, the Department of Education would ask the School Board to close it.
It is felt that the present arrangement provides most adequately for the education of our Indian children, and it is questionable if we could improve on the instruction presently available to these children.

The provincial school requires the pupils to walk about two miles, and transportation is somewhat difficult during the winter months. However, our field officers are making arrangements to see that the trail from the Reserve to the school is kept open, and it is not anticipated that these children will encounter any difficulties due to heavy drifts of snow.

I trust that this will explain the situation satisfactorily, and that you will agree that the old Goose Point School should not be re-opened.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Nesbitt:

I have now received a report from our departmental officers regarding educational facilities for the Indians of the Moose Point Band.

I am advised that there is a school building at Moose Point which was erected some forty-five years ago. It belongs to the band and is now used as a dwelling by the Chief. This school was operated by the Branch until several years ago when because of disrepair and the difficulty of obtaining teachers it was closed.

Due to no school facilities being available, the non-Indians who had sent their children to the Indian school made representations to the Provincial Government and a small provincial school was erected less than ten years ago. This is known as "Twelve Mile Bay School". It is a well constructed building, well equipped, good lighting, good blackboard space and inside toilets. At the present time, there is only one non-Indian attending this school. The remainder are Indian pupils and their tuition is paid for by this Department. Due to taxation of the numerous rather expensive summer homes in the area, the school finances are in very good shape and they are not dependent on the grant received from the Department for the Indian children in attendance. However, if the Indian children did not attend this school, the Department of Education would ask the School Board to close it.
It is felt that the present arrangement provides most adequately for the education of our Indian children, and it is questionable if we could improve on the instruction presently available to these children.

The provincial school requires the pupils to walk about two miles, and transportation is somewhat difficult during the winter months. However, our field officers are making arrangements to see that the trail from the Reserve to the school is kept open, and it is not anticipated that these children will encounter any difficulties due to heavy drifts of snow.

I trust that this will explain the situation satisfactorily, and that you will agree that the old Moose Point School should not be re-opened.

Yours sincerely,

(Miss) M.C. Hoey,
Associate Private Secretary.

Dear Mr. Nesbitt:

I refer to your letter of October 12th, concerning educational facilities for the Indians of the Moose Point Band.

You will be interested to learn that the Superintendent who has recently been appointed to the Parry Sound Agency has personally investigated the trails to which you make reference, and states that it is not the intention to use these but two old logging roads which can be improved and connected to the Indian settlements. He reports that the Mactier Council intends to spend $500.00 in work on the roads. He has also reported that a team of horses can be secured to provide transportation during the severe weather in the winter.

I attach a photostatic copy of a rough sketch which indicates that there are three Indian settlements in the area which the provincial school is able to serve. If, however, the school is reopened at King's Bay, the provincial school on Twelve Mile Bay would undoubtedly close for lack of enrolment. This would deny educational facilities to the three children who live close to Martin's Saw Mill and the six pupils who live on the reserve which borders the Twelve Mile Bay.

I should also add that the Inspector of Schools reports that he examined the register at the provincial

....2
school and "was surprised at the high attendance of our Indian pupils".

You will appreciate, I am sure, that it is most difficult, if not impossible, to secure teachers in the middle of the school term.

Although the majority of the children reside on the reserve at King's Bay, it would hardly seem that the department is justified in taking steps to open the school there when it would result in lack of school facilities at the other two points.

Yours sincerely,

(Miss) H.C. Hoey,
Associate Private Secretary

Ottawa, January 24, 1920

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th instant, enclosing a return from the teacher of the Moose Deer Point School for the month of December last.

This return is not satisfactory. The teacher should prepare a return for the quarter ending September 30th showing the attendance and days taught during that period and also a return for the quarter ending December 31st. The Department is paying him salary in full for both these quarters and a cheque has been sent him care of Capt. William Martin, Penetanguishene. You will be good enough to have the teacher make out new returns for both the above quarters and have them sent to you for transmission to the Department.

It is expected that you will give this matter your prompt attention and see that these returns are properly made out by the teacher and forwarded to the Department as soon as possible.

A cheque for the bonus due the teacher is being sent to you and you will be good enough to see that he receives this cheque.

A supply of blank quarterly school return forms have been sent to the teacher as requested by him and when he receives instructions from you to prepare new returns as directed above, there should be no delay in him doing so.

Your obedient servant

C. J. Picotte, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Penetanguishene, Ont.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated January 27th and contents noted.

The teacher of Moose Point School was here a few days ago and I gave him instructions as to how to make his return. I brought some quarterly school returns from Christian Island and sent them to him Jan 27th by Capt. Char. Martin, and I will forward them to the Dept. as soon as I receive them.

I think that all the correspondence, charges, stationery etc., for Moose Point School should be sent to me, especially when navigation is closed in the summer time mail is delivered in close proximity to school.

Capt. William Martin lives here all winter and Capt. Charles Martin his brother lives at Moose Point. He comes & goes often and always calls in to look for anything in regard to school, he understands the written.

Your humble servant

C.J. Picotte

Building up at Moose Deer Point School.
Dear Mr Scott:

I came down a few days ago from the Bay. I visited the school, which was open. They are now in an old log house, just a single room, in which they have a stove and some desks and benches. I saw all the children put through their paces, and I was very much pleased to see how they are getting on; one or two of the children could read quite long words like "returning," and other words of three syllables. The main result, however, of starting the school has been the very marked improvement in the elders, who seem to take more interest in keeping their houses tidy and doing a little gardening; whether this is the effect of the atmosphere of the school, etc., or of prohibition I do not know, perhaps a combination of both.

As to the reserve - I hope you will be able to stop any possibility of the cutting of any of the little hardwood under the old timber license; I think this is under the old timber license that many years ago covered everything, but there would be no hardship whatever in the Government, so far as the reserve is concerned, refusing to renew the license as to that part; if they do not they might as well not give the reserve. I should think it would be sufficient if the grant
was made to include the portions south and west of Twelve Mile Bay, but if you send somebody up, he had better get hold of Joe Sandy, who will show him all about by boat; he will find Joe most intelligent.

The Indians are very anxious to have a little school built which will give proper accommodation and air, etc., and they are clearing a little space at the end of a bay where it would be convenient. I told Joe Sandy to tell the others that I would ask you to say that you would pay towards the school, say, $500, which I think would buy the lumber and shingles and the Indians themselves could do the work. Joe had a quotation from Napoleon Payette for the erection of a school, and my recollection is it was $925, but I think if the Department would, on the certificate of your agent there that the school had been erected, say that you would pay for same to the extent of $500, that the Indians might well do the rest.

To my mind, the interest you have taken in this group, if the school is built and the reserve is set apart, will result most beneficially in making a number of Indians good citizens, and sober and industrious. There is a little bickering from some other Indians at Parry Island, and elsewhere, largely I think instigated by religious rivalry. Miss Tobey is a Catholic but does not attempt to bring religion into the school, and I fancy that one or two outsiders, who are strong Methodists, think she might attempt to introduce religion. I warned her against having any dispute of this kind.

Sincerely yours,

D. C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
September 24, 1917.

Dear Mr. Nesbitt,-

I have your letter of the 21st instant and am pleased to learn of the improved conditions among the Indians at Moose Deer Point, also that the children are making progress in their school work. With regard to a more permanent building, I have to say that, when we have the matter of the reserve finally settled, I shall be pleased to make a reasonable grant to provide better accommodation.

Mr. White, Surveyor of this Department, is leaving for Toronto to-night; he will consult with the Department of Lands, Forests & Mines and then proceed north to make a selection of land for the reserve. He will also call upon you and any help you can give him will be greatly appreciated.

With regard to the timber license, I hope that we will have sufficient influence with the Hon. Mr. Ferguson to have the lands selected for the reserve eliminated from the timber license.

Yours sincerely,

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, 11th October 1917.

Report on school at Moose Point, King's Bay.

Sir,

With regard to the school at Moose Point, King's Bay, which has been named "Kanonsiyo" or Happy Home I may say that the building in which they held school last year was not available and the school was moved to Mr. Joe Sandy's house on lot 55, Con. 7. There were eleven children in attendance the day I was there and everything seemed to indicate that especially good work was being done. Children who did not know a work of English a year ago had learned to speak it fluently and were reading well from the Second Book. Nearly all the pupils could count to 100, they were doing small sums and some of them were learning to multiply.

The teacher, Miss Tobey, likes her work very much but finds that the long walk to the school in the Fall and Winter has so impaired her health that she considers handing in her resignation. As she appeared to be making such splendid progress and seemed exceptionally able, I used my best endeavours to induce her to reconsider her plan and she said that if a school were built with a room in it in which she could live, she might stay all winter.

D.C. Scott Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
After completing the survey I exchanged what portion of the hardware I could for the following articles which are needed at the school,-

1 snow shovel

For the stove I obtained a credit of $3.75 in the name of Joe Sandy from M.A.Gendron. This will be very useful to procure little articles required in the building of the school; in any case the stove would only have been a waste.

SPECIFICATIONS
for
KANONSIKO SCHOOL,
ONTARIO.

This school is to be erected by members of the Band at their own cost, the material according to the accompanying list, being supplied by the Department. The work is to be done in the best and most workmanlike manner in accordance with the plans No. 402, Department of Indian Affairs, prepared for the same, and which clearly shows the dimensions of the building with the sizes of the materials and the general construction.

FOUNDATION.

Excavate to the depth of two feet for stone foundation walls which will be erected 16" thick on footings 5" thick, and projecting 6" on each side of wall above. The stones to be well packed and hearted each course and to have bond stones running through walls at least three to each yard of facework.

Plate of 2 x 4 to be well bedded on stone work on which joint will be laid nailed.

FRAMEWORK.

The framework will be erected on the plates, the 4" stud to be set at 16" centres and strongly nailed to plates.

The ground floor joists 2 x 10 to rest on plates and well nailed to the sides of studs, corners and all openings being doubled.

The partition between kitchen and class-room to be kept carried up full height of class-room ceiling and thence to top of bed-room ceiling.

The joists of bed-room will be set at 8' above ground floor as shown with inset to secure same and strongly nail to studs of framework, and trimmed for stairway, trimmers headers being doubled.
The rafters are 2 x 6 at 16" centres framed as shown on section drawing and strongly spike-nailed to roof plates, and having 1 x 8" ridge board supporting the rafter.

The ceiling joist of class-room to be set on roof plate and strongly spike-nailed to plate and rafters with 4" spike-nails at 16" centres.

The walls to be boarded up inside and outside with good quality boarding, strongly nailed with two 2½" nails to each crossing of stud. The roof and sub-floor joist to be similarly covered.

The outside walls to have one thickness of waterproof paper on outside and inside with sufficient lap to ensure warmth, and strongly nailed in place with large headed nails.

The outside and roof to be shingled with good quality of cedar shingle laid at 4½" to the weather, and strongly nailed with at least two 1½" shingle nails to each 4" shingle on waterproof paper.

The shingles to be stained green on roof and rad on walls of building.

The cornice to be as shown with 7/8" dressed boards nailed to framed ends of rafter and having sheathing scuff all strongly nailed in place.

The inside walls and ceilings will be sheathed up with good quality tongued and grooved sheathing strongly blind-nailed in place with 2½" finishing nails, the wall to be put on floor the sub-floor to be similar to walls and covered with paper, then layed on end matched maple or birch flooring blind-nailed every 16" in length.

The floor over kitchen to be of pine without similarly laid.
WINDOW AND DOOR TRIM.

The doors and windows to be trimmed with a four inch plain band, without moulding, well and strongly nailed in place.

The windows to be double hung with best quality sash card and cast-iron weights and to have lifts and fasts complete.

The door to be hung with the best loose pin butts, outside 4 x 4 and inside 3½ x 3½ and locked with suitable locks.

PAINTING.

The whole of the interior of building to be sheeted up, including ceiling, will be painted two good coats of paint and oil. The priming coat to be thoroughly dry and well sand-papered before putting on of second coat.

The hardwood floor in class-room and teacher's room on ground floor, and pine floor on first story, will be given a good coat of oil before occupied.

The frame of door and windows and all cornice of exterior will have three good coats of paint put on as specified for inside work, the third coat being a flowing coat which must cover thoroughly.

STAINING SHINGLES.

The roof to be stained with good quality of Moss green creosote shingle stain put on as soon as roof has been laid and cleaned off. The shingles to be well saturated, with the stain to be well worked in between joints of the shingles, effectively covering the exposed surface of shingles. The sides of building will be similarly covered with light red shingle stain.

NOTE.—Since the plans have been prepared it has been decided to have the foundation one foot above ground instead of two feet shown on the plan.

Also that three windows of large size will be put on left-hand side of school-room instead of four windows on plan.
Ottawa, October 11, 1917.

Sir,

I have to inform you that it has been decided to supply material for a school at King's Bay, Moose Point and Mr. Picotte has been requested to get tenders from all the lumber merchants in Midland and Penetanguishene.

The size and shape of the building have been somewhat changed from that spoken of by Mr. White. It will be 16' X 32', with a small porch, the walls will be 12' high and there will be two rooms for the teachers' use. Instead of being sheeted on the outside it will be shingled, and no half inch lumber will be used. A sketch plan and outline specifications for your guidance in building are inclosed.

You should set your men to work at once getting the stone on the site for the foundation, and if possible, it would appear to be advantageous for you to consult Mr. Picotte and hasten the matter in any way possible. In this connection it will be advisable for you to get the lime at your earliest opportunity and have the wall built when the lumber arrives. The wall will be 16' X 32' outside, and 3' high, that is 2' below ground and 1' above and 2' thick, and you will use lime instead of cement.

It is hoped that there will be no delay so that the school will be ready to be occupied not later than the middle of November.

Your obedient servant,

Deputy Superintendent General

Sir,

Replying to yours of Oct. 25, 6-23, I beg to state that I went to Moose Deer Point, the following morning, and found out the following:

The distance between Parry Sound and Moose Deer Point is about 35 miles by gasoline launch. There is a winter trail 16 miles from Barnsdale station on C.F.R., to Moose Deer Point.

The distance between Christian Island and Moose Deer Point is about 30 miles by Gasoline Launch. The distance from Penetang to Moose Deer Point is about 15 miles by gasoline launch, and about the same distance from Midland.

The cost of the trip from Parry Sound was:
Gasoline Launch $20.00, and meals $3.00, making $23.00 in all.

The school building is one and a half stories 30 X 18 with porch 10 X 10, built on ceder posts. The land is all sodd.

The building seems in good condition but very much in need of cleaning up—that is to be painted. There is a cement foundation required 2 ft. high by 6 in. thick. The outside and inside are badly in need of paint.

At the end of the building inside, there has been a portion partitioned off for the school master, this should be pulled down and the whole space utilized for school purposes. There should be another light put in, 6 by 3. Ventilation seems good. The ceiling is about 11 ft. high.

There should be an addition put on back of building 10 by 18, which could be used for a wood shed and for other purposes.

The eaves and gable ends of the school have never been caised in, and to give the building a completed look, this should be done.

The shingles should be stained and a belfrey built, and a bell provided as the building is used for church, for Protestants and R.C. religious purposes, also community hall.

There are homemade desks and seats in the building, which should be replaced by modern school desks and seats.

The seats and desks required are as follows:

| 3rd         | 2      |
| 2nd         | 4      |
| Sr. Ist.    | 1      |

I think it is too late in the season to put in a foundation, but the other repairs could be gone on right away. The school-master tells me that he can carry on in his house while the alteration would be going on inside.

The supplies such as lumber, nails, cement, paint, tarpaper, windows, and so forth, can be procured at Midland, Penetang or Parry Sound.

I can get a man, an Indian of Parry Island qualified to superintend the work, and who would do all that is required and pay the men employed for $400.00, all materials to be supplied by the Department. This, I think is the better way of getting work done, as the Indian, when put on time without somebody being responsible, I have found that he is careless of his time and not too attentive to his work. This school is situated in a nice bay and is the source of attraction for tourists in that vicinity, so much so that some of the summer residents provide prizes for the pupils.

Please reply at your earliest as owing to checking up of log stovewood cut I am busy but anxious to look after the school part of this agency.

Trusting that this will be satisfactory,

I have the honour to be,

SIR,

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) John M. Daly,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 11th, 1924.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the last instant, regarding the repairs, painting, addition, etc., required to the Moose Deer Point Indian Bay School building, I beg to say it is regretted that we were unable to provide in our Estimates for the next fiscal year an amount sufficient to carry out these improvements, and they will therefore have to stand over for another year.

Regarding the fencing, you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the quantity of woven wire fencing and staples required, and have the fence erected. It will be necessary for you to obtain competitive prices, if possible, and you should purchase the wire and staples from the firm quoting the lowest price. If any gates are required, competitive prices should also be obtained before the purchase is made. You should first ascertain the quantity of fencing required, and also whether the Indians will provide the posts and any labour. As soon as you have this information, you may arrange to purchase and forward the wire. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred, to which should be attached a memo showing the names of the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted.

I may say that last summer a quantity of paint was supplied the teacher for the purpose of painting the teacher's residence. You might enquire as to whether he used the paint for this purpose or not.

In your letter of October 29th, last, regarding the improvements required, you stated that new desks were needed. If you still consider that these are absolutely required, you should furnish full shipping directions.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant reporting that when Harry Meduayosh, an Indian of Parry Island, was conveying wire fencing by water to the Moose Deer Point School grounds, the boat capsized and the wire fell into the water, and in reply I may say that it would appear from your letter that the accident was the result of rough weather. If such was the case, and if the Indian was not careless in handling the boat, the Department is prepared to consider the question of allowing him payment to a reasonable amount for salvaging the lost fencing. It is observed you have stated that his original charge for transporting the fencing was $15.00.

A voucher in his favour may be submitted for payment. It should be made out for the amount which you consider he is entitled to receive.

Sir,

Replying to yours of the 12th inst., 22-3-5, I beg to state that all the wire which was lost in the lake in transit to Moose Deer Point School, has been salvaged and has been delivered at the school.

I had a talk with Harry Medwayosh re the salvaging of the wire, and suggested to him that as he had to make two trips to Moose Deer Point, with the wire I would allow him at the rate of a double trip, but could not allow him for the three days which he spent in salvaging the wire, along with another man.

I think that while he is not quite satisfied with this arrangement, that it is the best way out of this peculiar position.

Enclosed please find bills for that amount.

Ottawa, September 24, 1929.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit of inspection to the Parry Sound Agency.

Mosedear Point school is in very poor condition inside. This school is used as a Church and Community Hall. It needs painting badly both inside and out. The box stove at present in use is cracked and worn out. A new one should be installed. Three new window blinds are required. A teacher's desk is needed. There is a table in use at present; it is unsuitable. Three window lights are broken. The closets are dirty and badly in need of repair. Both closets are under one roof. The building needs to be sheeted outside and a new roof put on. The boys' section requires a new door and urinal. Both closets should be thoroughly cleaned out and scrubbed. This school, at present, is in charge of Bert Sutherland, with no academic qualifications. I understand a new teacher is being appointed at the end of this year. There are 16 children of school age in this section, only 5 on the roll.

Thos. McGookin.
Inspector.
Ottawa, September 30, 1929.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McCoockin, in a report on his inspection of the Moose Deer Point Indian Day School, states that the box stove at present in use is worn out and recommends that a new one be installed. He also states that three new window blinds are required and that a teacher's desk is needed; also that three window lights are broken and that the closets are dirty and badly in need of repair.

You should arrange for the purchase and delivery at an early date of a stove of the type considered by you to be satisfactory to heat this building. If any stove pipe is required, you may also supply same. You may arrange for the purchase and installation of three window blinds of the sizes required, and for the supplying and installing of the three window lights. Relative to the teacher's desk, you may purchase and forward a desk of an inexpensive type.

You should arrange to have the closets thoroughly cleaned and placed in a good, sanitary condition. The Inspector states that both closets are under one roof and that this building needs to be sheeted outside and a new roof put on. The boys' section requires a new door and urinal. You should arrange to have the repairs required made to the closets.

The purchase of the above supplies, and repairs to the closets, should be carried out as cheaply as possible, and accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred.

The Inspector further states that the school building requires to be painted, both inside and outside. It is thought that this work might stand over until next Spring, but if you consider that it should be done this Fall, I shall be pleased to have an estimate of the cost of the material and labour required.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

Replying to yours of January 8th, 22-7-5, re bill of $5.50 for hotel accommodation for Mrs. Gingras teacher for Moose Deer Point School, this bill, in my opinion, is very reasonable, and I have to state that I do not know of any other way of looking after a teacher than the way I have done in this case.

For the information of the Department, I have to state that according to instructions received in yours of Nov. 4th, 22-7-5, "Mrs. Gingras will arrive, Parry Sound, Tuesday morning Nov. 5th," and as November 5th and 6th were very stormy days, it was impossible to go to Moose Deer Point. I tried to go to Moose Point, but the boat livery people refused to take me. It wasn't Mrs. Gingras fault, that the weather was so boisterous, neither was it mine, and as I had instructions from the Department to look after Mrs. Gingras, and as I considered it my duty as an official of the Department to do so, therefore I think it is reasonable that the Department should defray the expenses, which were kept at the lowest possible figure.

It has been customary since I came here to look after the little children going to the schools, and I have kept them in the house with me here, but I do not think it is reasonable to expect that I should accommodate the teachers in my house. I would therefore return the bill and ask the Department to reconsider their decision in this case, as I told Mrs. Gingras when we were held up by the storm that the Department would look after the bill. I told her this because I thought it was the only reasonable thing to do. If the Department think I was wrong in making this statement, would they please say so, and I will see that the bill is paid, as I think it the only gentlemanly thing to do.

Mrs. Gingras was prepared to go on the 5th to Moose Deer Point. We could not make arrangements for her to go
because of the storm, we went on the 7th.

I cannot see why the Department should not pay this bill.

Trusting this explanation will be satisfactory, and that a cheque will be sent forward to Mr. Gilchrist to pay this bill.

I have the honour to be,

Mr. Inspector McGookin, in a report on his recent visit to the Moose Deer Point Indian Day School, states that this building requires painting inside and outside and that this work should be done next summer.

I have, therefore, to request that you will bring this matter to the attention of the Department next Spring, at which time you should state the work you would advise be carried out and the approximate cost of same. You should also state how you would recommend that the labour in the painting and any other work required should be carried out.

The Inspector states that four new window shades are required, and you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of these shades of the required size. Please forward an account, properly certified, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I have had conversation with Chief Isaac of the Moose Deer Point Band, and he informs me that the teacher of the school is arranging to board herself, and intends living in the school. There is a small cubby hole upstairs in the rear of the school which she figures, if it were fitted up, would suit her. She figures making this change after Christmas, and has sent the following requisition with the Chief, for consideration:

- ½ gal paint, cream colour, for walls.
- 1 quart grey paint for the floor.
- 1 window shade 38" wide.
- 1 granite potato pot.
- 1 iron frying pan,
- 1 butcher knife.
- 1 big fork
- 5 ft. of zinc, by 3½ ft. wide, and the same amount of asbestos.

I am not in favour of this woman living in the school alone. If you interview Mr. McGoogan, he will tell you what I think about this woman, and because of my spoken sentiments to him I cannot be in favour of her living alone in the school. I would appreciate having your opinion about this, but I am not in favour of this woman living by herself in the school in this cubby hole upstairs.
If you talk this matter over with Mr. McGoogan, the Inspector, he will tell you what I think about this woman from the appearance of her when she returned here this fall for duty.

The chief will be back here on or about the 8th of November, I will appreciate it very much if you could let me know if these supplies will be granted.

An early reply will be appreciated.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Sup'ty. Parry Sound

JMD)EK.

The Department is not in favour of having the teacher fitting up quarters and residing in the school building. You will be good enough to inform her accordingly.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 25th ultimo and previous correspondence, with reference to the painting of the Moose Deer Point Indian Day School, I have to inform you that you may arrange to have this work carried out as soon as possible, provided you are able to secure a satisfactory quotation covering the cost of the paint and other materials and for the labour. If you consider it more advantageous, you may arrange for the purchase of the paint, etc., from a firm on the list to receive consideration and engage the men to do the work. It is noted that the lowest quotation you received was that of C. L. Falstrem, for the painting of the school buildings and toilets, for $195. In this connection I would refer you to the estimate of $110, which you submitted in your letter of May 19th, last, for the painting at this school.

If you consider Mr. Falstrem's quotation to be reasonable, you may arrange with him to perform the work - he to supply all material and labour. However, if you believe it would be cheaper for you to purchase the materials and arrange for the labour, you may do so. You should see that all costs are kept as low as possible. It is understood that the buildings are to receive two coats of a good grade of paint, outside and inside.

After the work has been completed to your satisfaction, please forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

The Department will leave this matter in your hands, to make the best arrangements you can to have the work carried out at the lowest possible cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary,

John M. Daly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

Educational Division.

Re: Moose Deer Point School.

In a recent telephone conversation with Col. Neary, I had advised him that the new Township school on Twelve Mile Bay, close to the Moose Deer Point Reserve, had been opened and a teacher installed shortly after the first of the current month and that I had notified Lena Williams, who has been carrying on to the best of her ability the teaching of the younger children on the Reserve, that she should now close up her school and let all the Moose Deer Point people of school age attend public school.

I find that there has arisen some objection to this amongst the Indians and have had some correspondence with Mr. Wallace Rankin Nesbitt of Toronto on the subject. Mr. Nesbitt has a summer place close to the Moose Deer Point Reserve and has always been very much interested in the welfare of the Indians there. His father took a leading part in having the Reserve established some 30-odd years ago and Mr. Nesbitt himself has been prominent for the last few years in an endeavour to have the Department provide these people with educational facilities. I am enclosing a copy of a letter which I have received from him on the matter of the children attending the new school.

We have for several years canvassed all the possibilities at this point and finally decided that the establishment of a public school there would solve our problems and since this has now been done, I cannot see any reason for making any other arrangements. A number of the Indian children live on the side of the Reserve which borders Twelve Mile Bay and are within very reasonable distance from the school. It is a fact that most of
the younger children live on the other side of the Reserve but not at a distance very much more than one mile from the school and in such an isolated community, I do not think that this should be any disadvantage.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Superintendent.
Samuel Devlin, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Parry Sound, Ont.

Dear Mr. Devlin:

I have yours of January 10th and quite appreciate that Lena Williams is not qualified to do any teaching beyond the very elementary and kindergarten grades, also that the Department would prefer to have the children start in the new school at Twelve Mile, but the old school house at the village is still in my opinion sufficiently serviceable to handle the very young children, and it is immediately adjacent to their living quarters, as against the new school being well over a mile which means a long hike for the babies.

Would it not be possible for you to continue the smaller ones under Lena at the old school house and advise the more senior ones which she is not capable of dealing with and to whom the long walk through the woods is not as arduous to the new school. I think that if you adopt this you will find no difficulty with the Indian objections that are there at the moment. The small cost to the Department to continue the babies in the old school under Lena would I think be negligible alongside the satisfaction that the Indian population there would obtain. If you require any backing in Ottawa for this suggestion I of course would be only too delighted to do so.

Yours very truly,

W. R. Nesbitt.
January 17, 1950.

Dear Sir:

An inspection of the Moose Deer Point Indian reserves was recently made and during the course of my visit I walked through from the Twelvemile Bay Indian settlement to the new Twelvemile Bay School. It is a good half-hour walk through the bush to the school from this point and I presume for small children it would take them proportionately longer. The trail is in fair condition in some places but at several points is wet and swampy and needs brushing out. The time and distance from King's Bay or Weh-Wah-Teysee settlement is longer but the trail is in fair condition.

At the time of my visit, there were five Indian children and three white children in attendance and two more Indian children will begin school September 25th, when their parents' work at a nearby Lodge is completed for the season. At the present time, the residents of King's Bay are employed in the fruit areas but on their return, I hope to be able to persuade them to have their children attend as well, of which there are at least five of school age.

In an effort to promote and maintain a good attendance, as well as assist the younger children, would it be possible to obtain authority to purchase cocoa, milk, sugar and possibly soup to provide a hot beverage at noon for them during the winter months. As there is no way of getting these supplies in at minimum cost during the winter, it would be necessary to make the purchase of sufficient supplies for say five months, sometime during the latter part of October.

In addition, I believe, for an expenditure of approximately

I have about 8 more children starting to school and therefore we have to enlarge our class-room. We have to use the teacher's living room to enlarge the classroom. Ottawa, April 29, 1920.

Sir,

Mr. Bert Sullivan, teacher of the Moose Deer Point Indian Day School, in his annual report for the fiscal year ended March 31st, last, states that it is necessary to enlarge the class-room, as there are a further number of children who will attend in the near future. He states that it is necessary to use the teacher's living room to enlarge the school-room. The Department understands from his report that the Indians would do the work of enlarging the school, if they were supplied with the necessary material, and the teacher would like to have a small four roomed cottage built to provide living quarters for himself. He also states that they intend to put a stone foundation under the school this summer.

I have to request that you will be good enough to furnish a report setting forth your views as to what you consider would be required to be done to the present building to provide class-room accommodation for all the Indian children who would attend, and also to provide suitable living quarters for the teacher. As the timber on this reserve is under license, you should state where the necessary material required for the above purpose could be obtained and also state the approximate cost of supplying the quantity of lumber and other material required.

Good results are being accomplished at this school and the Department is anxious to assist in any way that it can to provide educational facilities for the Indian children.

You will be good enough to look into this matter thoroughly and report at an early date, giving full particulars as requested. It is presumed that any labour required would be performed by the Indians, if the Department supplies the necessary material.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. J. Picotte, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Christian Island, Ont.

In the year 1917 the Department had a reserve set aside for certain non-treaty Indians resident at Moose Deer Point, on the Georgian Bay. In the same year a school was established, and in 1918 the Department supplied materials and the Indians erected a new building. The teacher at that time was an Indian girl who lived at home. Last year a teacher named Mr. Sullivan was appointed, and he has been residing in a portion of the school-room which was partitioned off for teacher's quarters. This space is now required for the accommodation of the children, and it is proposed to erect a small residence near the school for the teacher. The Indians will do the work and the Department has obtained prices for materials which will enter into the construction amounting to $588.

Sir:

I have to report that I have taken Mrs. Gingras, the school teacher, to Moose Deer Point and according to the reception that we received it would appear to me that Mrs. Gingras will be quite popular there. I have made arrangements, as stated before for Mrs. Gingras to board with the Martin family, who are the caretakers of the Honourable Wallace Nesbitt's place.

When going through the teacher's house at Moose Point, Mrs. Gingras let me know that she would prefer to have her own place. I took a rough estimate of what would be required to make this house habitable. I have to state that this is a log building and has been allowed to go into disrepair. It has been painted with green paint in the inside and beaverboard has been used to line the walls, but owing to the house not being in use, this beaver board has buckled up and would have to be torn off. There would have to be a stairway put in and the inside of the place altered.

Enclosed is an estimate of the material that would be required to put this place in first class shape. There would have to be a foundation put in which I estimate would take about 25 bags of cement. There is lots of sand right there. By putting in this foundation the Department would be justified in the expenditure for the repairs.

I think it would be wise to have this house fixed up as soon as possible so that the teacher may get settled down to her business. As near as I can estimate it, it would cost $328.10 to fix up the teacher's house and I would like to state that when this place is fixed up, it will be good for ten or fifteen years, perhaps longer.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Stanley Williams, a member of the Moose Point Band, is desirous of purchasing from the Department the building on the Moose Point Reserve which had been used as a teacher's residence. His idea is to wreck this old building and salvage whatever material possible for use in building a house, which he intends to erect for himself on the Reserve. He has made me an offer of $40.00 for the building and will be prepared, in the event of his offer being accepted, to pay cash.

The building referred to is a log house of two stories and is in a very tumble-down condition. It has not been in use, I believe, for seven or eight years, as the former teacher had not resided in it, but had made her home with a nearby white family who are caretakers of a summer place in the neighborhood. In looking this building over last year, I had come to the conclusion that should a school ever be reestablished on the Reserve, it would be more practicable to build a new residence for the teacher, rather than attempt to repair the old building.

With regard to the offer of $40.00, I do not think that the material it might be possible to salvage for rebuilding would be worth any more than this sum.

Samuel Devlin,
Indian Agent.

October 1st, 1947.

Dear Colonel:

Re: Government Grant Indian Day School, Moose Factory.

I am sorry to have to bother you on the above matter, but the M.S.C.C. auditors in Toronto are paying us a visit on Monday and Tuesday next week, and have requested that certain information be made available for them. In regard to the item above mentioned, I think I can do no better than quote from the letter received from the audit firm this morning:

"While you were absent in Saskatoon, I was inquiring from Mr. Forward about the receipt of the Dominion Government Grant for the Indian day school at Moose Factory. It is necessary to obtain the amount of this grant in order to prepare our financial statement for the Moose Factory day school in connection with the Province of Ontario Grant to the school.

Mr. Forward inquired from the Treasury Department of the Indian Affairs branch and they informed him that for the year 1946 a grant of $620.00 was paid in connection with the grant to the day school. Mr. Forward was not able to trace the receipt of this money at the Ottawa office, and we could find no trace of receipt of it at M.S.C.C., Toronto. Mr. Forward wrote to me that the Treasury Department had informed him the cheques were made payable in each case to the school teacher concerned at Moose Factory, and sent to Bishop Renison for distribution, and he has requested the Department to endeavour to lock up the cheques and see who endorsed them and where they may have been deposited. It is possible that the cheques were either cashed at Moose Factory and used locally on behalf of the school affairs or that they were turned over to Bishop Renison for use in the finances of the Diocese of Moosonee.

In any case, if Mr. Forward has not informed you of the situation, could you make further inquiries from the Indian Affairs branch, so that if possible there will be some definite information of this matter when I arrive in Ottawa next week."

I would appreciate very much if you could give me by Monday the information which the auditors desire.

Yours very truly,

G. R. Turner,
for Superintendent.
Ottawa, October 7, 1947.

Dear General Turner:

For the quarter ending March 31 this cheque amounted to $189.00 and was drawn in favour of the teacher and sent to the Right Reverend R. J. Remison, Bishop of Moosonee. This cheque was No. G 194/17 and was dated April 25, 1947. It was cashed at the Canadian Bank of Commerce in Ottawa on June 17, 1947. It was endorsed by Miss Hooper and bore the stamp of your Indian School Administration below her name.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,

Dear Colonel Neary:

Government Grant
Moose Factory Indian Day School

I regret very much the need for troubling you again on the above subject.

On receipt of your letter of 15th October, I sent a copy to the Auditors in Toronto hoping that it would give them the information they want but I have now received a reply from which the following are extracts:

"The information from Colonel Neary concerning the cheque for $252.00 appears to cover the last two quarters of 1946, although the phrasing "for the period September 30th to December 31st, 1946" might cast some doubt as to whether one or two quarters are involved. It would be of interest to know why no Return and therefore no payment was made for the June quarter 1946 as I believe some grant should be expected for that quarter. Also, there is no mention of what grant was paid for the first quarter of 1946 to complete our information for the calendar year of 1946.

"Mr. Forward wrote us on August 23rd of this year that he had learned that the grant for 1946 was $620.00 but I have no information as to how this amount was made up and it does not seem to tie in with the information we have recently received from Colonel Neary's office.

"As the grant for 1946 must be shown on the Return to the Province of Ontario which we are at present..."
preparing, I am anxious to confirm whether this amount of $620.00 is the correct grant for 1946.

"If you can make further inquiries from Colonel Neary's office, I will be most obliged because this Provincial Return should be made as soon as possible in order that the Administration can obtain the proper grant for 1947.

"The situation created by this grant of course only makes more clear the necessity for your office to have a detailed list of what grants are to be expected from Indian Affairs and Provinces in order that the proper amount of grants are received at the Ottawa office."

If, therefore, you can let me have some information that will finally satisfy the Auditors, I shall be obliged.

Referring to the last paragraph of the quotation from the Auditors' letter, I am only too aware of the difficulties caused by lack of information in this office on the normal grants that you make us during the course of a year. I am endeavouring to compile a list but it is a slow business and I have no guarantee whether it is complete when it is compiled. If you could let me have, at your convenience, a list of such grants with their amounts, it would be of very great help.

Yours truly,

G. R. Turner
for Superintendent

Ottawa, October 30, 1947.

Dear General Turner:

Re: Moose Fort Indian Day School

We have your letter of the 22nd inst., with reference to payment of salary of the teacher at the above mentioned school.

It is regretted that official letter of October 15th, 1947 read "September 30th to December 31st, 1946". This should have read "September 1st to December 31st, 1946", or in other words, it covered the amount we allowed towards the teacher's salary for the September and December quarters. Monthly payment of the teacher of this school was $63.00 or $630.00 a year.

In official letter of October 7th we advised you of the payment of $189.00 for the quarter ended March 31st, 1946. This amount plus the payment for the September and December quarters made a total payment for the calendar year 1946 of $441.00.

We did not make any payment for the June quarter 1946. The return for the quarter ended March 31st, 1946 was signed by Miss Alice Davies. September and December quarterly returns were signed by Miss Louise F. Hooper.

We reviewed our files and find that we received a return for the quarter ended June 30th, 1946 but it was signed by the Rev. Henry J. Cook. We do not appear to have been advised of
his appointment as teacher of the day school and consequently no payment was made at that time.

We will arrange to have a cheque for $189.00 in payment of the June quarter 1946 forwarded to your office. When this is received it will mean that the total payment of $630.00 for the year 1946 will have been made.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Government Grant
Moose Fort Indian Day School

In our letter of 9th January, 1948, we asked for information regarding payment for the quarter ending 30th June, 1947.

In your reply (44-7-3(WT) of 19th January) you advise that payment for that quarter was made by cheque No. 36116 drawn in favour of Rev. H. G. Cook for $189.00 which was mailed to this office on 8th November, 1947.

May I invite your attention to the last paragraph of your 44-7-3(WT 1) of 30th October, 1947, and your 44-7-3(WT 1) of 26th November, 1947, which indicate clearly that cheque No. 36116 issued in November, 1947, in favour of Rev. H. G. Cook was in payment for the June quarter of 1946.

In view of the above, may the question of payment for the June quarter of 1947 be looked into, please, and this office advised as early as convenient.

Yours truly,

G. R. Turner

My dear Mr. Stewart:

I am sorry for the delay in forwarding accounts, but I have been prevented by the very serious illness of Mr. James, for besides personal attention, I have all the responsibility of his work. Sorry to say that he is still very ill, and we have cabled for his release.

As you will see, I have corrected the accts. as made out by Mr. Oxley, and am sorry to find that they are especially the provision acct.—double the sum he made out. In his anxiety to make the accts. appear reasonable, he has left out the amt. on the addenda. You will also see that I have changed the accts. for buildings by making out the list of material for school, which includes all the lumber, windows, doors, &c., stated in the first acct. The "additional buildings acquired" too, I have withdrawn, being the large store & woodshed in connection with the School, which are not new—these placed entirely at the disposal of the School. I can assure you that after thoroughly overhauling the Hudson's Bay accts. I am more than ever perplexed as to how they managed to spend the sum they have, and still more indignant with the Hudson's Bay Co. for advancing, without my authority, to this amount. I distinctly told Mr. Oxley and Miss Johnson that not more than 12 to 14 children were to be taken in, and that the expenses were to be kept down. From Miss-Anable in Aug. last I sent them down a $50.00 outfit of provisions, which is not included in the provision acct. enclosed.

Altogether
Altogether the expenses of Moose Fort School will not be covered by $2000, apart from the school grant of $500. There are many details in the H. B. C. acct. which I have not included, and besides these there are many other items such as servants' wages, firewood, planting, hay, etc. The expenditure was simply reckless. If I am privileged to get down to Ottawa this Winter I will bring the H. B. C. a/c with me and I think you will, like myself, be disgusted with them for allowing accts. to run up to such figures. Their only excuse, when I remonstrated with them was that they were under the impression the Indian Dept. were supporting the school, but even supposing they were, they had no right to presume upon that.

From an educational standpoint very good work was done, but the cost was cruel.

After deducting the grant kindly made by the Dept. of $1500. for equipment the Diocese will be responsible for over $1000. including the extra items mentioned above, but for this the H. B. C. will have to wait.

Had I done in Athabasca what Mr. Holland and Oxley did at Moose I should have been made responsible for every cent I had spent over the sum allowed.

The only fault I found with Mr. Oxley's work was the outrageous expenditure.- As you will see from the details of the accts., nothing was spared. And I was assured that the two Indian girls they had in the kitchen were carrying off provisions and other things wholesale. In no other way could they have used all the flour and sugar but especially 113 gall. of coal oil.

Yours very sincerely,

Geo. Moosonee.

Dear Sir:

The Ven. Archdeacon Renison B.D. has instructed me to furnish you with the cost of the new day-school here, which is herewith enclosed.

This new day-school is just being finished and furnished so that it will be opened to receive pupils at the beginning of the New Year.

The new building is 42 ft. x 21 ft., and will accommodate 120 pupils. It is a very substantial building, being of solid logs, and lined both inside and outside.

The total cost of this day-school, as per enclosed memorandum, is the sum of $1364.61 and towards this expenditure the Depart. of Indian Affairs has already Made a Grant of $500.00.

In reference to said cost of building, I have considerable experience in such matters, and I think that the same building out at the LINE would cost at least $2000.00.

The Archdeacon wishes me to ask your Depart. of Indian Affairs for a supplemental Grant of $864.61 to meet this outlay.

There are over 100 pupils' names now on the school register and many more entries could be made if we had accommodation for them.

I beg to inform you that the quarterly Report is herewith mailed you under separate cover.

Yours respectfully,

Rev. A. McLean Banting,
