Here be:

1. An appointment of Teacher for the Reserve School in the Moravian Reservation, Kent Co., has to be made, to fill the place of Mr. Wm. McFarland who leaves at end of this year.

2. The enclosed correspondence from Mr. Tobias seems to indicate that every Indian on the Reserve (except the few who have candidates of their own) desires to have Mr. Tobias reappointed.

3. Mr. Tobias while teacher in 1893 was convicted of horse stealing and served 13 months in Central Prison. This is the solitary objection to granting the unanimous wish of the Indians on the Reserve.

4. In favor of granting their petition I beg to submit the following facts:

   Mr. Tobias was convicted on purely circumstantial evidence and many thoughtful persons believe that he was not guilty, though he may have been mixed up in the matter. The Rev. Mr. Hartmann, resident minister and myself believe he is innocent.

   His conduct from his boyhood until that time, his conduct during his confinement and his conduct...
since then both parent and child have been most exemplary.

He is an active church worker and a leader in the Christian Endeavour Society.

III. He received his training under Rev. W. Ashton at the Mohawk Institute and at Bradford Collegiate Institute graduation as a regularly qualified school teacher in the schools of Ontario, and he is an excellent disciplinarian and a skilful instructor. He is eminently better qualified for this particular school than any one else available as he is a native with reserve and humor every parent and every child and speaks their language, as well as being a good English scholar and an all-round clever fellow, as you can judge from his correspondence enclosed.

IV. I think the school will do much better under Mr. Tobin than under any inexperienced white person; he was very successful when there before, and he secured a far better attendance.

I am of the opinion that the crime charged against him 5 years ago, which I do not believe, and which evidently the Indians do not believe, I think it would be wrong to keep him down by still punishing him when he paid the penalty and been discharged, with very high credit for his conduct by the authorities.
VI I believe that the appointment of teacher in an Indian school is made by the Indian Agent on the recommendation of the School Inspector and is ratified by the Indian Department. I shall, if you deem it advisable, recommend Mr. Tobias for the Moravian Reserve School for the ensuing year.

Honored Sir,

The policy of the Indian Department has been to lift the Indian to or help him place himself upon a higher social and educational plane and before the elections we were promised more voice in our own local affairs if we helped sustain the Liberal Party. We did so.

I have the pleasure to send you herewith copies of two petition (one by the Indians, one by the prominent white people as well as those in the immediate neighborhood of the Reserve) that I be appointed Teacher of the Reserve School here.

I have written on the recent examinations held in the County Model School, Chatham to obtain a renewal of my 3rd Class Provincial Public School Teacher's Certificate. My original certificate...
obtained in Brantford Collegiate Institute has been in the possession of the Indian Department since 1870 or 91, and as it is customary to hand in the original for indorsement would you kindly return me the original certificate sent you by Mr. Beattie, then Indian Agent.

I believe I am the only Indian in Western Ontario who obtained a regular Provincial Certificate and by appointing an Indian when he becomes qualified a strong inducement is placed before the eye of other Indians to strive for a higher educational plane. Besides that with me just now it is a case of great need, more so than with my white folk competitors.

I suppose the appointment rests with the Agent and Inspector. If from the favorable reports of my efficiency as teacher sent you (1892-93) when I was teaching this school before, you can mention me favorably to Mr. Agent McDonald you will confer a lasting benefit on me. Besides the petitions—which mark the people's confidence in me here are testimonials also. I have written to the Trustees.
Praying that your wise and kind policy will sustain my application.

Believe me,

Your most obedient humble servant,

Reverend Sir,

The last of my writing in the school has just been finished (3 sheets). How I wish the journeying ended too. I shall have traveled over two hundred and fifty miles sometimes taking but one meal per day, besides being at times much exposed. The support of a man in your position to one in mine is worth much greater effort than the little I have made. If you had not opened the door I would not have started, so whether I win or lose I shall be grateful to you. Your letter will go with my papers to Ottawa tomorrow.

I shall be glad when it is over. Would you kindly let me know the result as soon as possible, but I know you are very busy so do not write till then. I suppose it is the anxiety and worry over this that has taken away both my appetite and much sleep yet I shall rest now for my work is nearly ended.
If I fail in getting this one where my own people want me, I shall not try again among strangers. Five testimonials have been subscribed, and if necessary I can get more.

To Mr. McDonald it may be merely an appointment, but not only a position nor a salary to me. It is everything.

Hopefully yours,
Willie F. Tobias.

Dear Sir:

Tobias came in to see me this morning and after considerable talk with him, he signed the paper which you left with me, but not until I had changed it to suit an objection which he made and that was that his signing the paper should not prejudice his right to his last quarter salary. I assured him that it would not, and that his rights to that would be just as strong after signing as before, and that I would undertake for you that his position on that point would be as I stated.

He stated to me that Gillis at Highgate had his cheque and insisted upon keeping the whole of it, though he was quite willing to have him take out of it what advances he had secured from Gillis upon the strength of it, but Gillis would not accede to this and demanded the whole of it. Dear Sir,

Regarding Jacob Logan's fabrications of which you spoke to Mr. Huff the other day and for permitting which he (God) was rather severe on me. I would state that if you feel any doubts in this matter a letter to Mr. Douglas, magistrate, or to Mr. Coulter (who made the arrest) both of Melbourne P.O., Middlesex Co. Ont will convince you that I had nothing to do with the matter. A letter to Myles Mc Donald would show at what time I arrived at his place and went to bed. There was a full house of grown up people and three children.

I myself will make no statement whatever unfortunately for myself I incurred the suspicion having stolen a location ticket from your P.O. There is no satisfaction in footing a bill of $20 dollars for a lawyer letter ordering him Jake, shut up. I attempted a case once paid the lawyer telling me I would have to prove damages before I could claim any and paid Joe Huff for delivering a useless lawyer letter. I get all the damage that such cur's tongues can inflict thus have the pleasure of footing a bill for getting some professional to tell them not to say such nasty things about me, without a cent of expense smile quietly at their success in causing me a deal of annoyance and outlay.
It's much more satisfactory to give him a good punching and then pay out money in a just legal fine for he then has a few bruises to console a better tongue.

Both Isaac Hill & Job Whiteloon (who brought the news here) as well as Jack have passed and re-passed barely one block from the magistrate's and constable's house in Melbourne and I dare say have never stop asked about the truth of their statements, possibly for fear they would have nothing to talk about.

If I get a handle to by which I can cause them any expense or financial loss in a law suit or send them to prison I'll use it to the very last inch.

Respectfully yours,

William Hobbs

P.S. I am told that you are going to money. If so you will find out the name of the farmer who lost the straps. I think he said Thompson or Johnson or Lomas. I may yet be able to ask to take up a case of slander. I am told that I paid $30. If I can nail such a statement down I will do so.

W.M.T.

SCHOOLS.

FEB 2 1900

Dear Sir,

I have the honor to report in respect to Willis Tobais late teacher in Moraviantown Reserve, that I found upon visiting Mr. MacDonald's agency, that he had not suspended Tobais, but that he had upon the 22nd. of December 1899 come to an agreement which terminated Tobais' services. Upon that day Tobais told him that he would not teach the school any more.

I had notified Mr. Tobais to meet me in Muir Kirk, and not finding him there at the hour I arrived—though he had been there earlier in the day—I sent a conveyance with a request that he would come over and see me. He sent an equivocal answer and did not come.

On a subsequent occasion I endeavored to bring about an interview with him, but fruitlessly. So I took measures to compel his coming under pain of being punished for contempt, until by declaring that he did no longer consider himself a teacher of the Department, nor had he any claim to be the teacher of the Moraviantown school, he withdrew his conduct from what would be a proper sphere of inquiry.

I enclose herewith a memorandum addressed to me by Mr. Tobais which shows that he no longer claims to be a teacher of the Department and under such circumstances I cannot see that there is any necessity to further investigate his conduct, which would more properly be the subject of criminal proceedings.
I enclose for the information of the Department two letters dated respectively December 4th., and December 26th. 1899 from A. Douglas, Justice of the Peace, addressed to A.K. McDonald and would say from my inquiries, that it is clearly the general opinion that Tobias has been mixed up in theft and other sharp transactions. I have seen the boy referred to in these letters, Angus De Lauch, who is in jail here serving 90 days hard labor, and although he will not confess that W. Tobias was an accomplice of his, by the way that he speaks of the harness theft in which he was concerned and about Tobias suggests strongly that he is shielding the latter.

I found that Tobias is living in a small house with a white woman and her two daughters, whom he is said to maintain, and the circumstances which certainly give the gravest reason to suppose that there are improper connections.

I quote from the "Highgate Monitor" of Thursday, January the 11th. 1900, the following passage,

"Every effort was put forth by ex teacher Willis M. Tobias "to find errors or even dishonesty, but the public considers the "Toronto Record and that possibly he may take a degree at Kingston".

The reference to the "Toronto Record" is to the incarceration which he suffered there, of which the Department is aware, and the suggestion that he might take a degree in Kingston made in this public manner is made in respect to the theft of the harness and other articles which had taken place in the vicinity of the Reserve in which he is supposed to be in some way connected.
I think there is no doubt that Tobais' unwillingness to meet me was because he feared that a meeting might probably lead to a criminal prosecution, such as he had some difficulty of escaping in connection with the theft of the harness.

I recommend that the matter be allowed to stand in the position in which the agent put it, that is to say,- That Tobais, by agreement, ceased his teachership in December 1909 and is not under suspension or in any way connected with the school of the Department.

Yours obedient servant,

Ottawa, January 13, 1909.

The Deputy Supt. General,-

Mr. Gordon, M.P., who forwarded a letter addressed to him last month by Mr. Nethercott, asking for the appointment of his son as teacher of the Moraviantown Indian school, which is vacant, at a salary of $500, was informed that if Mr. Nethercott was willing to take the school at the salary at present available ($400.00) the Department would be pleased to avail itself of his services.

The Rev. Mr. Nethercott, the Methodist Missionary at Moraviantown and father of the young man, has written the Department, saying that Mr. Gordon had sent him its letter and that his son would not accept the school at less than $500 a year. He is said to have a First-Class Certificate but the only recommendation the Department has is from his father. The Band pays the salary and, if it were increased to $500, they should be consulted, if it was to be charged against them.

J. Pliny S. Nethercott, for whom the application is made, is at present teaching at Shetland, Ont., and I do not see how he could take the Indian school at once as he would be required to give reasonable notice.

There is ample opportunity for a good teacher to make a success in the Moraviantown school. There are about sixty children of school age on the reserve, all living within easy access of the school. The last quarterly return shows that
that there were 48 pupils enrolled, with an average attendance of only 25. Nearly all the pupils are in the lower standards, 35 being in the third or lower standards. The Moraviantown Indians are all Methodists and with the Father as missionary and the son as teacher they should be able to secure a regular attendance and better results, if they were sufficiently interested in the education of the children to exert themselves. On the other hand, as this young man is the son of the Missionary, it might be difficult to keep him up to his work, if he was inclined to be negligent.

It seems to me that the Department should have further information about this young man before engaging him at this rate, which would be the highest salary paid to any day school teacher by the Department. It would not be too much to pay to a teacher who had proved himself successful, but until we have evidence of his ability and earnestness, the Department would be taking chances. I would suggest that he be asked to apply by letter under his own hand, stating his age, experience, physical condition and inclosing his testimonials. He should also state when he could take charge of the school, if his services were accepted. It is for the Department to say whether it would pay $500 as an initial salary. The school is closed, and immediate action should be taken.

Department in paying my salary monthly, he continued to me during the first quarter, namely July 1st to Sept. 30th— and that this be considered as one of the terms of the engagement.

I shall write you relative to my experience thus far in the school, and endeavor to give a few of my plans for the future, should my application be accepted.

At first my task seemed a very difficult one, owing to the apparent inability, on the part of the
Department in paying my salary monthly, be continued to me during the first quarter, namely July 1st to Sept. 30th—and that this be considered as one of the terms of the engagement.

I shall write you relative to my experience thus far in the school, and endeavor to give a few of my plans for the future, should my application be accepted.

At first my task seemed a very difficult one, owing to the apparent inability, on the part of the
pupils to understand me when I spoke to them, having for more than five months listened to, and spoken, almost exclusively, the Indian language. This difficulty has become less and less.

I set myself the task of learning their language. I found that even a few words that I could speak to them in their own tongue, seemed to open the door wide, to the hearts of both pupils and their parents. I am still studying the language occasionally, as I am able.
I give parts of a lesson in the Indian tongue, and require one of the pupils who understands English quite well, to give what I have said in English. I find this delights the pupils, and they never forget that information, and its expression in English. I never allow them to answer in their own language during school hours.

In developing my method of teaching the English language thoroughly, I have repeatedly felt the urgent necessity for a library.
in the school. I would like to put in an urgent plea for the installation of a library, of the correct type, even though small at first - if no more than fifty volumes. If it is my privilege to return to the school, I would humbly request the privilege of giving some expression, as to what books are suitable to the needs of a school such as this is.

I might say, that there is scarcely any help towards the development of the habit of independent research and study, in a settlement like
this, where books are so very scarce.

Mr. MacKenzie, while here mentioned the matter of supplying occasional lunches for the children. I had previously made no investigation in this respect, but have done so since. I found that while some were amply provided for, others, in my judgment, had not what was adequate nor sufficient for a child in need of physical vitality and mental activity.

My purpose, if return to the school, is to spend a considerable portion of the
holidays, after we are moved and settled here, in visiting every family on the reserve. I hope thereby, with my wife's assistance, to stir up greater interest in the things that make for the improvement and elevation of the race.

I hope that you will pardon the length of this letter. I will excuse myself by saying that I endeavored to be brief.

I remain,

sincerely yours,

George A. Snider.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

In accordance with instructions received I visited the Moraviantown Indian school on the 16th ult.

There are 62 children of school age on the reserve and out of this number 31 were in attendance, 14 boys and 7 girls. During the previous week the attendance had been as high as 39 and not lower than 30. The falling off was due to many of the parents having left for Hamilton with their families to engage in berry picking.

It is not necessary to make any remarks on the building. There is seating accommodation for all the children of school age. Before the desks are placed in the new school-house they should be revarnished. They have a good supply of books, maps, etc., of which good care seems to be taken. The room was very clean and tidy and the children were neatly clad.

The teacher, Mr. Snider, is a married man. He holds a second-class non-professional certificate and a Model School diploma. I spent part of both the forenoon and after noon in the class-room and was fairly well pleased with the work being done. One feature is commendable; that is the attention paid to Nature study. I had the pleasure of listening to a lesson on "The Rose", taught with the flower before the pupils. This was a combined observation and language lesson, the children being required to express their observations in complete sentences, which were then written on the board. If Mr. Snider is retained in the
position he expressed his willingness to conduct a garden in connection with the school next summer, which is something the Department has been trying to encourage in its schools for some time past. The writing and drawing of the pupils were good and a brief examination of their reading, arithmetic and geography showed that these subjects were not being neglected. Of course, allowance has to be made for the four and one-half months the school was closed and the short time Mr. Snider has been in attendance.

The usual diffidence of Indian pupils was very marked in this school. It is a most difficult matter to get them to speak distinctly and loud enough to be heard. Some suggestions in this respect were offered the Teacher. In regard to discipline Mr. Snider's work would bear improvement. In his efforts to obtain the confidence and goodwill of the children he has allowed them, in my opinion, too much latitude. Naturally timid, they did not, I was given to understand, take very kindly to a male teacher. For some time the teachers in this school have been ladies. One can appreciate the difficulty of Mr. Snider's position; on the other hand he appears to have been too lenient, and seemed it is a hard matter to correct the evil. He seemed to be quite conscious of the defect, to which his attention was called, and I hope to see an improvement in this respect.

Mr. Snider has so far, on account of boarding some two miles from the school, taken no interest in the home life of the Indians. The importance of this work was impressed upon him, and, should the Department retain his services,
I think he can be relied upon, when he takes up his residence near the reserve, to make an effort to interest the parents in the education of their children, and in this respect there is apparently a field for his labour.

He impressed me as being enthusiastic and energetic. He is a man evidently imbued with the missionary spirit and in work of this kind activity in that direction may more than counterbalance any deficiencies in his capabilities and methods as a teacher, provided he exercises a proper control of the school-room.

In this connection I think the regulations should, if possible, be enforced on this reserve. The school is centrally situated, and there is no reason why nearly all the children should not receive the benefits of the education offered. As one of the Indians said to me, "With a $3000 school-house and a high salaried teacher, the parents should be compelled to send their children to school". The same view was expressed by the Secretary of the Council. It may be that Mr. Snider's efforts and work among the parents will produce good results and that the existing indifference will to some degree at least disappear.

On the whole I am of opinion that the Department could not do better than engage Mr. Snider as teacher of this school on the terms already offered.

Sir,

I am writing to ask that the Department will do me the kindness to send me a payment on my salary at the end of the present month, Nov. 30th. I am loath to do this, but it is evidently a necessity, both for our own needs, and also on account of some to whom we are indebted.

I am minded also to write somewhat relative to the school work here. I had hoped on returning to secure a place to rent on the Reserve, so that we might live amongst the people whom we hoped to benefit.
In this I was disappointed; but secured a house off the Reserve, a mile from the school building.

I am endeavoring to find a solution of some of the problems connected with Indian education, two or three facts have come under my observation, which have led me to contemplate a change in the modus operandi in connection with the school here.

I find that many of the young men and women, who have gone through the school, are unable to converse in English, and are consequently evasive and reticent in demeanor. This also hinders their progress, and helps to keep them among their own people.
Some of my best pupils in book work are handicapped in this way. To elicit a conversation from them is apparently an impossibility.

There are two or three families of which the parents have been off the Reserve a considerable portion of their lives, and consequently speak English in their homes. Their children come to school and learn the Indian language through playing with their schoolmates.

These, with a few other considerations, and my desire to overcome these difficulties, have led me to a conclusion with the permission of the Department; I would turn this school temporarily into a kindergarten, not in building houses, etc., with blocks, but in building
sentences, words and phrases in oral expression in English. I would take my children to the real objects with which they have to do in everyday life. I would point them out to them and the facts relative to them about which we are to speak. I would speak the words of the conversation, in English first, and require my pupils to repeat them after me; individually first, then in unison. And then I would require all who can to write them.

Outside of the regular language lessons, I have had two lessons of this nature, of one hour each, and have met with marked and noticeable results, which have encouraged me to continue with hope of success. I would continue this practice.
regularly until my pupils could converse with me readily upon any subject of common everyday interest.

Of course this would necessitate frequent departures from the regular routine of school work. I would have to take my pupils to the neighboring fields where grow the different crops, to the many groves nearby in search of the different kinds of trees; to the barns of nearby farmers, who were willing to observe and converse about the different kinds of stock, grain, and fodder, etc., etc.

This work would be interspersed with a sufficient amount of other work, in mathematics, the theory of language, reading, word recognition, Geography, and the other subjects on the curriculum. A school garden in the
Spring would also be very helpful in furnishing additional material for this work.

The prosecution of the plan of work outlined above, I believe, contribute much towards the present greatest necessity of the pupils of the school here, the development of the power of oral expression in English—the language of this land—and would be effective in overcoming one of the greatest barriers to Indian progress—their inability to understand fully, and express themselves fluently, in English.

I remain,

sincerely yours,

George A. Snider.

A Story of a hickory nut

A hickory nut grows on a tree. On the top it has a green shell, and inside it has a white shell, but it's very hard. It is not altogether round. But its top shell comes off very easy in the fall, after the frost comes and freezes it a bit, and it falls to the ground. It lives on a tree when it has other brothers and sisters which fall with it. And when they all fall boys and girls come and pick them up, and put them in bags and take back the top shell off, and put them by the stove to dry, and then they put them into the cellar and keep them in the winter.

The white shell of the hickory nut is like coals, for it makes a good hot fire. A hickory nut has something inside of it which is very good to eat. Sometimes three or four hickory nuts grow on a bunch.

A Story about Summer & Winter

I am going to take the pleasure of writing two stories at once; they are about Summer and Winter. But I am going to write about Summer to tell you what I do in Newmarket. In the summer I play about barefooted and sometimes go to the river and fish and many a time I bath. Once caught a fish seventeen inches long. I'll tell you I had a hard time pulling him out—a bass mind you. Of course some boys have caught bigger fish than that—I guess. But this fish he broke one hook and one line before I caught him. I have caught fish every time I have gone out to fish. I am sad to have good luck every time I go out fishing. One day my father and I crossed the river and fished. He beat me being seven to six. Why I like fishing so well that I'll never stay home on Saturdays down to the river I must go. So of the people on this reserve fish on Sundays but I don't. Sometimes I play ball run and jump and sometimes hot corn and other things I need not mention.

So this is all I need to say about Summer. Let me tell you next what difference there is between Summer and Winter.

Winter

In the winter I go out hunting rabbits and things like that, and in winter there is snow on the ground and ground is cold but in summer time you would never see snow but land would be hot as any. Bare feetboys have to keep out of the hot dust in the summer. But in the winter time the barefoot boys have to have warm shoes on, and I suppose they would like to have a stove with them when they go out of the house. They need warm clothes, warm houses and warm beds. But in the summer time you need cold bed, cold air, cold bath—and last of all you need thin clothes. In the summer I think I'll tell you what I do in winter. I play snowballing and throwing snowballs at something to learn how to throw straight. Sledding is most important one for me many a time when men would go past our place with a load of wood to the oil wells and when coming back I either jump on the sleigh or take my own little hand sleigh and sit it to the big sleigh and sometimes I have a coast down a hill and now I will close.

Not having received blank forms for school report for December quarter as yet, I am writing this informal letter to the Department of Indian Affairs. I received official letter of the 24th ultimo. I appreciate the willingness of the Department to extend the time limit of my stay here, notwithstanding the evident determination of the Inspector of Public Schools, to oust me from my present position forthwith.

I have enjoyed considerably my past year's work in the school here. I have been able to gain a firmer grasp of the situation, a better knowledge of the needs of the work, and a more thorough understanding of the people, their customs, manner and ways, etc., etc. The results achieved among the school children have been...
I think even more satisfactory than during the preceding year. I think that the degree of sympathy with the school work, manifested by the Indian people, has been considerably increased. I think that without exception, I have the affection, confidence, and respect of my pupils.

As to the report of the Public School Inspector for West Kent, to which reference is made in official letter above-mentioned, I beg to repeat that which was stated in my former letter; that the Inspector's marked change of attitude towards my work, as well as his two later deleterious reports thereon, are due to considerations which have no bearing whatever upon teaching, teaching ability nor school work.
And I think that the facts at my disposal are sufficient to warrant me in coming to this conclusion.

It is not my purpose to lay claim to exceptional ability as a teacher. Nevertheless, in addition to the facts, as already stated in my former letter, I beg to say, that previously to any reports, favorable or unfavorable, issued by the Inspector of West Kent; five competent Inspectors of Public Schools in the Dominion of Canada, had made inspections of my work as a teacher and all reported favorably. Three of them are college graduates (with degrees), and teachers of experience in both public and high school work.

The cause underlying these schemes and intrigues to wrest from me my present means of making a livelihood, is simply
a matter of religious prejudice, or misguided religious zeal. The fact is that the standpoint from which I view religious truth, is one that is distasteful to the authorities on religion in these parts, of whom the Inspector of schools is one.

My attitude in these matters is this. My faith, worship, and service are toward God. But I am not a believer in, nor a worshipper of the "ism" that prevails throughout the land, which has become to some, the Diana of the Ephesians, declared in ancient days to be so "great." Acts 19:26, 27, 28.

Your obedient servant,
George A. Snider.

Sir,

I beg to add another to the list of informal letters already forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs relative to the work here in connection with the school. I am not writing this to give occasion of annoyance to the Department, but rather to avoid further unnecessary annoyance.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6146, File 413-1, part 1)
It will be remembered that a requisition was sent in to the Department some time ago, asking for ink-wells for the school here. Specifications were given as to diameter at the larger extremity. When the ink-wells arrived, none of them would fit. All were too large. It was decided, that to avoid further delay, it would be better to have the apertures in the desks enlarged.

Accordingly an Indian carpenter was engaged to do the work. He
gained access to the school room, on a Saturday, soon afterwards, secured the ink-wells, took them home with him, and then reported to his chief that he had no instrument with which to do the work. Efforts have been made by both the Indian Agent, and the Chief of the tribe, to secure an instrument for this work, but without success as yet. So that the work of the school is being conducted, as formerly.
independently, as far as ink-wells, or the authorized copy-books are concerned.

Let it not be supposed by the Department of Indian Affairs that the exercise of writing has been neglected in the school because of this. Writing is, in my judgment, but a medium of expression, as is language. So that, in the teaching of writing, I give my children something to write, and they write it. The method in detail, as far as it...
can be given here, is something like this:

A "story", of some three, four, or more links, is "built up"; the pupils of the class furnishing the material, which the teacher writes on the blackboard, as each child gives it to him. The whole story is then read aloud by the class, sometimes individually, and sometimes in unison.

It is then erased from the black-
board, and the pupils are simply told to "write it;" which they generally do, with an approach to accuracy, which is often quite remarkable. The pupils receive commendation for doing so well. The "story" is then re-written by the teacher for the pupils to write, and re-write until the work is accurately done.

In favor of copy-books it may be said that they are additional aids to the correct formation of individual
letters; whereas against them it may be charged that they contribute somewhat to the formation of the habit of tracing rather than writing.

I enclose a few samples of work done in pencil by pupils from 7 to 10 years old, who but a few months ago could not write a letter nor read a word. I might say, as a postscript, that the subjects chosen in the beginning are always
those with which the children are most familiar, and in which they are most interested, as "cat", "candy", "bird", "mouse", "play", etc., etc., etc.

Our chief barriers to progress are irregularity, and prejudice, about which I may write later.

I remain, sincerely,

Your humble servant,

George A. Snyder

As intimated in my former letter, I am writing to enumerate a few of the difficulties to be met with in connection with the school work here at Moravian town. Of course the chief obstacle to progress is irregularity in attendance. This is a weakness which might be said to characterize all the phases of Indian life.

But there are a few who have ventured sufficient confidence in the teacher, to give expression to their candid and sincere reasons for not sending their children regularly to the school. A few of the objections, as they have been given to me, are these.

It is claimed that the "best-educated" Indians are the laziest ones; that the "biggest rogues" among them have been...
highly favored in the way of educational advantages; and that the children who study much come to think more of books than of toil.

Their girls are increasingly irregular after they reach the third book, Standard four. They either "hire out," or stay at home to "keep house" for their mothers. They, with the latter, also assist in the putting in of the crops.

A man living just across the road from the school building has three children of school age. They are all quite clever. He seldom sends them to school for more than half a day at a time. They are kept at home for periods of from one to three weeks. They can be seen daily playing in their own yard just in front of the school building, while the other Indian...
children sit at their tasks in school. Sometimes they are all three taken with their father to the field when he goes to work, which is generally about nine or ten o'clock A.M., and two P.M.

His argument is this. 'He lost his best child through sending him to school, and he is going to save the lives of the rest if he can.' It seems that their eldest, a boy of eleven, died, some three or four years ago. It is said that the Doctor claimed, that his sickness was due to over-study at school. It is said that the boy was proficient in music, as well as in school work. They are very affectionate towards their children. The father teaches them vocal and instrumental music at home.

Your obedient servant,

George A. Smith

Ottawa, June 13, 1911.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th instant confirming the telegram forwarded by you on the same date in which you accept the position of teacher of the Moraviantown Indian School.

In reply I beg to say that the Department is pleased that you are undertaking this work and trusts that you will be quite successful.

There is a splendid field on this reserve for an energetic teacher. A new modern building has been erected and all the conditions are favourable. The work differs little from that in the ordinary rural public school in Ontario, but a teacher requires special tact in dealing with Indian pupils and Indian parents. One of the most common obstacles to success is the apathy of the parents and the consequent irregularity of attendance by the pupils and the experience of the Department shows that this can only be overcome by the personal efforts of the teacher.

I may say that the Department has no special directions to give you, but would be very pleased to afford you every assistance possible after you commence your duties and I shall be glad to have short monthly reports from you on your work. The Indian Agent, Mr. A. R. McDonald, who will visit the school monthly, will be informed of your appointment and also asked to afford you any help that he can.

MEMORANDUM:— Mr. Pedley.

The Department engaged Mr. J. B. Pengelley to take charge of the Moraviantown Indian Day School after the summer holidays last at a salary of $500.00 per annum. Mr. Pengelley has not a permanent professional certificate, but he has a non-professional certificate and also had a course in the model school. Mr. Pedley,

On November 14th, last, a recommendation was made to you by the Superintendent of Indian Education that the salary of Mr. Pengelley, teacher of the Moraviantown Indian School, be increased from $500.00 to $600.00 per annum. Mr. Pengelley's application was not approved at that time. In a recent communication he states that he must again ask for an increase and you will find herewith a letter from the Agent, Mr. Beattie, enclosing a resolution from the Moreviantown Council that the teacher's salary be increased to $600.00.

In the previous memorandum reference was made to the very favourable reports of the Public School Inspector. Mr. McKay has just returned from a visit to this reserve and he states that there is marked improvement in the school generally. The enrolment has reached 95 per cent of the children of school age on the reserve, with an average attendance of 57 per cent. Mr. Pengelley is popular with the parents and pupils, which is a great consideration, as popular and efficient teachers for Indian
Indian schools are rare. It would be greatly to the advantage of the school to retain his services, which can only be done by paying him a liberal salary. Conditions are such on the reserve that Mr. Pengelley has to walk a mile and a half to the nearest white farmer's home, where he obtains his board. The former teacher, who proved himself a failure after two years trial, received the same amount as Mr. Pengelley.

The Moravians appreciate Mr. Pengelley's services and can well afford to pay the increased salary. In view of their resolution and the excellent results obtained as shown by the reports received I would again recommend that he be paid at the rate of $600.00 per annum from the first of the present year. It is so seldom that an Indian Band makes a recommendation of this kind that the Department would do well to give its approval when it would be justified in doing so, as in the present case.

On referring to the last report of the Minister of Education for the Province of Ontario I find that the highest salary paid to male teachers in the rural schools in the County of Kent was $1000.00, female teachers $600.00 and the average for the 140 teachers in the rural schools of that county was $548.00. Conditions in an Indian school are not very congenial and the only way to offset the disadvantage is by offering a substantial salary to a deserving teacher.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR W.H. COLIES ON THE MORAVIAINTOWN SCHOOL.

Teacher,- George Gillard.

Mr. Gillard's "success" is hard to estimate. Out of 64 eligible pupils, a mere 11 choose to come to school. Mr. Gillard's own explanation is,- "They say I'm only a kid and ain't got no influence over them.

The number of children of school age is large- 64- and the one opportunity to influence them for good and mould their characters is in providing a teacher with strong individuality and moral force.- a person of experience, maturity and sense of responsibility. But here we have an innocent harmless young man, whose personality and influence are nil, and instead of being able to hold the school together and impart some degree of enthusiasm to his pupils, he merely accepts such as choose to come and spends his time teaching them. Though a well meaning young man, Mr. Gillard is not the kind of teacher, who should be chosen for such a school. He does not appear to be taken seriously by the people on the reserve, though he does his best according to his light. The Inspector should be consulted in the selection of a teacher for this school. It will take a long time to overtake what the children are now losing, with 11 present and 53 absent. The school has retrograded since Mr. Gillard- since Mr. Gardiner left it.

Mr. Gillard probably does the best he can, but this school should be in charge of a man of a different type. No teacher of character and standing will teach such a school for $500.00 a year.

On behalf and with the consent of the Council of the Moraviantown Band of Indians I beg to state that the present janitor of the school does not do his duty faithfully or well, and has not been performing the proper duties of his office for a considerable time back.

The school is never in a cleanly state. The walls of the school rooms and every part of the building is dirty. The basement of the building is in a very untidy and dirty condition. The closets for both sexes are in an intolerable and unsanitary condition.

Notwithstanding that the council has repeatedly pointed out to the janitor the improper condition of the building and the grounds and his neglect of duty the official still continues to allow things to go on as they have been for sometime past. I would respectfully solicit on behalf of myself as chief and the council of the band that an official of the department come to the Moraviantown school and investigate it. Should you determine to send an inspector or official to examine the condition of affairs I would suggest that no notice be given before hand of the official's visit as the janitor on being made aware of the approaching visit takes care to have the grounds and school in a good condition.

The council has repeatedly objected to him for his carelessness and neglect of his duty, but he pays no attention to our objections or requests. The council by resolution has dismissed him from the office, but he continues to disregard the notice of dismissal and holds the office.

I would respectfully request that the Indian department officially dismiss him and have its agent see that the request of the department is carried out.

Yours truly,

Washington Jacob

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit for the consideration of your Department a special supplementary report upon the Indian school on the Moravian Reserve, Orford Township, Kent County.

Upon the 1st instant, in company with Mr Abraham, Field Agent for the Department, I visited this school and Reserve for the purpose of starting a School Garden and arranging for teaching and experiments in Elementary Agriculture and Horticulture.

The Forenoon was spent in the School where addresses were made to the Pupils by Mr Abraham and by me, and in the school ground, where the location of the garden was discussed and plans proposed.

In the afternoon we made special observations of the agricultural conditions on the Reserve in order to learn what are the needs of these people and how best their condition can be improved.

I was glad to observe that the chief recommendations in my former report have been carried out and that there are radical changes for the better in the school, proportionate I judge to the increase in the attendance from 11 to 58, the number present on that day.

The teacher Mr A Beith Gardiner has the confidence of the Indian people and the children are getting the benefit of the school instead of lying about home as they did under some of the former teachers. Mr Gardiner is much interested in the work and would like to
continue for another year, but I am informed that a lady has been engaged to take the school after midsummer, and I would say that unless she be very much better than the average she will not be able to keep this school together as it is now. And unless she have special training in Agriculture she will not be able to carry out the work which we are now starting by means of a school garden, and which the children are quite eager to take up. Where you have an Inspector that takes a lively interest in the school I think he ought to be consulted as to the teacher who shall be employed.

Our observations outside the school lead me to suggest that the Government be asked to construct main drains to which tile drains can be run through the farms, as most of the land is "sour" and will never yield profitable crops until it is tile drained.

Secondly that say four teams of horses be furnished by the Department, to be used in turn, under the direction of the Indian Agent, as few of the Indians have horses of their own. Implements also would have to be lent in the same way for a while.

Thirdly a teacher's residence should be built near the school and a married man permanently engaged to teach the school and look after the school garden. There is great need to promote industry and better methods among these people, whereby they could well become self-supporting and even prosperous.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

Your letter is before me approving the appointment of Mr. H. L. Leeson as teacher of this school, at a salary of five hundred dollars ($500) per annum. Without giving any assurance that the amount would be the same I, of course, informed Mr. Leeson that the salary now being paid was $600. I further understood that the Local Council had paid Mr. Gardiner an additional $100 per annum on account of special instruction in agriculture which was carried on in connection with the school, and intended to take up the question of the possible continuance of this grant on behalf of Mr. Leeson.

Dear Sir:

You will recall our correspondence touching the salary of the teacher, Mr. H. L. Leeson, at the Moravian-town Indian Day School. I negotiated with Mr. Leeson on the assumption that the salary paid would be the same as that received by the former teacher, namely $600. When word came from the Department that on account of the applicant's lack of experience the salary would be reduced to $500, Mr. Leeson hesitated about accepting the position. On further representations the Department agreed to engage him at a minimum rate of $500, and the assurance that if he rendered satisfactory service the question might again be raised of returning to the figure paid to the former teacher.

Some time ago I met Mr. Leeson, who told me that the Inspector, W. H. G. Colles, had visited his school and expressed himself as well pleased with the results being attained. I do not know whether the report of Inspector Colles has yet reached the Department. If it should prove satisfactory I beg to express the hope that the Department will give favorable consideration to paying Mr. Leeson at the rate of $600 per annum. At the present scale of wages in almost every direction, I think we are particularly
fortunate in securing the services of a young man of this type for one of our important Indian Day Schools, at what is after all a very reasonable rate of remuneration.

In this connection I beg to state that a note has come to hand from Mr. Leeson saying that he has received no salary to date after some two months of service. I had of course assumed that the amount earned in September would have been included in the third quarter of the year, and paid early in October.

Yours truly,

The school appears to be completely disorganized since the last term. The parents and the children need to be awakened to their duty and some compulsion should be used where truancy is persisted in. Dear Sir:

- Re Moraviantown School -

After receiving the notice of Miss McNaught's appointment as teacher of this school, and before Mr. Mathers left for Christian Island, I received word from Miss McNaught that she had been taken ill and would not be able to proceed to Moraviantown for perhaps a month.

First of all I asked Mr. Mathers to defer his departure and endeavored to secure temporary supply. At the suggestion of some of his friends at Moraviantown, I wired to Mr. H. L. Leeson, who taught this school last year but was then in Manitoba. Just at that time Mr. Leeson arrived from the West rather unexpectedly and after some delay has consented to supply the school for the present at least.

In the meantime, Mr. McGibbon, Inspector of Indian Agencies, had phoned me from Parry Sound, urging the early transfer of Mr. Mathers on account of the long vacancy which had already occurred at the Christian Island school. In view of this urgency and of the fact that only a temporary provision was involved, I took the responsibility of making provision to supply Mr. Mather's place at Moraviantown. This action is now reported in the hope that it will be satisfactory to the Department.
Mr. Leeson's engagement must be subject to the requirements of the Military Service Act. For most of the time since he came of military age Mr. Leeson was unable to enlist because of the effects of an accident. Although quite recovered from this he has recently been classified by the medical examiners as unfit for combatant service. This being the case, it is unlikely that he will be called in the near future, but in fairness to the young man and the Department, I thought this explanation was in order.

Teacher, - Mrs. Mary Louisa Yarwood
Qualifications,- III Class, expired 30 years ago, all traces vanished.
Experience,- About 12 years, mostly in the remote past.
Age,- I should judge 60 or more.
Condition,- Vigorous for her years.
Success,- Given time Mrs. Yarwood should be fairly efficient, especially if the children be compelled to attend school regularly. Truancy is the chief hindrance to progress, and changes of teachers is next.

The general management of the school is satisfactory. Mrs. Yarwood is an experienced teacher, but that experience has been carried down from a rather remote period and much has been lost, or forgotten on the way. Mrs. Yarwood promises to be more systematic in her work, and I believe she can and will do so.

Mrs. Yarwood has sensible ideas as to the condition of the school and premises, and as to what is required. The school garden is in good condition and is well planted, but the teaching of Elementary Agriculture should be more systematically taught. I am making an effort to have the teacher give more attention to this feature of the work.

The standing of the school is not as high as formerly, there being only 4 pupils in higher than I Form.
Extract from report of Inspector W. H. G. Colls on the Moraviantown Indian School dated May 31, 1918.

The people and their children are indifferent to the advantages of an education. The children are kept home to work or allowed to absent themselves upon trivial excuses, and spend much time fishing or playing in the woods. A forceful married man should be employed as teacher and a residence provided for him.

The attendance has been so erratic that there has been little opportunity for improvement. A teacher must have personal influence in the reservation in order to have the children come to school and take an interest in the work.

Extract from Teacher's Annual Report on the Moraviantown Indian School for the year ended December 31, 1918.

Original 160370-25F. ONTARIO

REMARKS.—The school work is too heavy for one teacher to do justice. The majority of pupils do not attend regularly and consequently are backward and very restless. As there is so little they can do without the teacher's constant attention, I have done the best I could under the circumstances but am not satisfied with results although a number of pupils have made fair progress during the year. Many times I have felt the need of help but could not afford to get any at the salary I have been getting. There are many inconveniences with which I have to contend make the work much harder. It seems to me if the mission and educational work were combined and a settlement house built and three workers associated there viz:- one for the mission work; one for the educational and a social service worker to visit the homes and give instruction in housekeeping and thus try to uplift the home life, results might be better. I just mention this as it seems practical to me. I feel interested in the people and would like to see their home life conditions improved as I believe it is the foundation of any race or nation.

================

Teacher

Dear Sir,

I visited today the Moravian Indian School to see how Mr. Doytator is getting on and whether he should be continued. He was the last one of ten applicants called upon because I was not entirely satisfied with him from his application. I find him an honest young man, anxious to get on and fairly competent as a teacher but he has not and never will have the influence upon the Indians that our teachers should possess.

He lacks virility and self-confidence and is consequently a little lax in discipline. I fear that if we get the children back to school he will have poor order. Meanwhile we must help him as much as possible. He may improve. I showed him what he requires and showed him how to govern his school, and I shall try to visit the school again before the end of the term.

I would advise making an agreement with him terminable upon a month's notice, and if he do not show himself capable I shall look out...

Minutes of Council Meeting, June 2nd, 1924.

Mov. Vot. & Car. that the Moravians in General Council, go on record as protesting against the present arrangement or agreement of the Methodist Mission Board and the Indian Department, whereby the teaching and the preaching were combined, we consider, that the Missionary Board has broken faith entirely with the Moravians, under the present arrangement. If from financial stringency or for any other reason, the Mission Board are unable to carry out the terms and conditions under which they were granted the use of the Mission Farm in 1902, why do they not acknowledge their default, and surrender any claim they might have to this property? Instead, they rent to a superannuated Methodist minister at a rental that he can well afford and does sublet to another at a good profit, while he himself resides in Bothwell, some 6 or 7 miles away. The house on this farm is unoccupied, as the party to whom Rev. Nethercott sublet this property occupies his own house. We consider Frank J. Joblin an excellent teacher and one of the best the Day School has ever had, but it is impossible for one person to make good in both professions, and we feel that both are suffering under the present arrangement, and would ask the Dept. to speedily re-arrange these matters, so that more progress might be made in both Church and School on this Reserve.

Your obedient servant,

Nelson Stone,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

Joe Whiteye, an Indian boy of my Agency, has not attended school since last mid-summer; he will be fifteen years old in June next, is only in first form of public School, and Mr. Joblin, the former teacher told me, that it seemed impossible for Joe to learn and also that he kept other members of the class back. Before my appointment, I am told, Jameison Whiteye, the father was fined eight dollars for failing to compel Joe to attend school. The new teacher, Mr. Knechtel, and the Truant Officer have complained to me and wished me to authorize the Truant Officer to hunt Joe up, compel him to return to Reserve and School. Joe has been absent from the Reserve since mid-summer; he is, I understand, an honest industrious Indian boy.

I talked to Joe and his Father, on this matter, and I am convinced that the boy left home and the Reserve to escape being compelled to attend school. He is so backward at school, that he detests attending and being branded a dunce, besides, there are seven children in family, and the Father complains, being delicate, that he can not provide food and clothing for this family unless the older children are permitted to work and earn their own food and clothes. I feel that it would not be in the best interest of Joe Whiteye, Whiteye Family, or the School to compel this boy to return to Reserve and School, and yet I do not like to allow the School Regulations to be broken, although, I think the teacher, Truant Officer and Agent should exercise their good judgement in these individual cases.

See next Page.
And do not think we would be justified in going off the Reserve and expending money in locating any pupil of this Reserve and compelling them to return to school.

Dear Sir;-

An unfortunate situation has arisen at Moravian-town. Mr. Mathers, who is the Missionary Teacher there, has accepted an invitation to Lion United Church, Brantford, and wants to be released from his duties at Moraviantown on the 1st of March.

He proposes that his wife - who is a graduate of Victoria College and holds a permanent Specialist's Certificate in Household Science and High School Assistant's Certificate (also permanent) - take charge of the school until a successor can be secured.

Mr. Knechtel, who rendered such fine service at Moraviantown for two years, could take charge on the 11th of April. He is now in attendance at College in Kingston and will be through his examinations by the date named. I understand that the Indians would be delighted to have Mr. Knechtel succeed Mr. Mathers, but he cannot do so until April 11th.

I have urged the Brantford people to wait until then for Mr. Mathers, but they seem reluctant to do so. We have had extensive correspondence about the matter - also personal interviews - and up to the present I have been unyielding in the matter of Mr. Mathers leaving Moraviantown before Mr. Knechtel is ready to succeed him. I am taking it for granted that it would be satisfactory to the Department to have Mr. Knechtel take charge of the school at Moraviantown in April and continue until summer holidays. Am I correct in this?

Now, what I write about today is this. Would the Department consent to having Mrs. Mathers act as School Teacher on the Moraviantown Reserve from the 1st of March until the 11th of April? I do not press the matter, but simply state the case and will leave it with you to consent, or otherwise, as you may be disposed to do. If you do not consent, I will use my utmost endeavor to have Mr. Mathers remain until Mr. Knechtel is free.

Awaiting your reply, which I hope will be by return mail, I am,

Very faithfully yours,

C.E. Manning

Dear Sirs,

Recently the local Board of the United Church of this district asked me what percentage of salary to J.D. Scott, the individual performing the dual duties of Teacher & Missionary was paid by the United Church Mission Board?

I find on making inquiry, that the Indian Dept., pay $850.00 for the ten teaching months of year, and the Mission Board pay only $350.00 for the twelve months of service as Missionary;

I had understood prior to making inquiry, that Dept., & Mission Board went Fifty - Fifty on salary.

To my mind the present arrangement is very one-sided; The Mission Board are not at present paying the Rent they collect from Mission Farm;

The Farm is rented for either $500.00 or $550.00 per year.

The residence occupied by Missionary is supplied by Reserve, fuel & repairs from Band Funds.

The Mission Farm was originally granted on the understanding that all revenue from same was to support the Missionary of the Reserve.

Dept., may say this matter is no concern of mine, but I view the matter differently; While I am agent or superintendent for this Reserve my chief duty should be to guard & protect the Rights of the members.

Yours Obediently,

Nelson Stone, Agent for Moravians.

Dear Sir,

Reports of misconduct on the part of the Missionary Teacher of this Reserve, "Mr. J. D. Scott" have been quite in evidence of recent weeks; I refused to listen or believe until on the 30th ultimo "Mr. E. K. Snake" the leading official of Reserve and local Church Board visited my office and stated that Mr. Scott had confessed his guilt when pressed by Snake for a true statement;

Snake agreed with me at once, when I expressed the opinion, that it would not be in the best interest of Reserve or Mission Board to allow Mr. Scott to continue longer than was necessary to get a Substitute.

I may say, that prior to this, several of the Parents of my agency, had registered a complaint to this office, and stated they would not attend church or allow children to attend school while he was in charge;

The misconduct consisted of the fact that for weeks Mr. Scott had been too intimate with a young married Indian woman with a husband and three small children, her stealing out nights and meeting him with his car and remaining out four and five hours from home;

You can readily conceive the effect of this would have when he was acting in the capacity of Missionary Teacher.

I wrote "Rev. C. E. Manning, D.D., Toronto, Ont., Sec., Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada" and today have his reply to the effect, that he appreciated very much my courtesy in writing him as I did, and to say that he was having his local Superintendent at Thamesville, investigate and report to him; and it would seem that it would be imperative to remove Mr. Scott, but they had an ordained minister and qualified school teacher that was immediately available.

Do not consider it necessary for Dept. to take any action or interview the Mission Board, but I wished to acquaint the Dept. with the circumstances.

Yours Obediently,

Nelson Stone, Ind. Agt.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of January 9th (No.15-1-1) re the situation at Moraviantown Indian Day School.

Immediately after Mr. Stone, your Agent for this Reserve, reported the rumors he had heard about Mr. Scott, who is the teacher at Moraviantown, I communicated with Rev. Leonard Bartlett of Thamesville, who is Superintendent of the Moraviantown Indian Mission under the United Church of Canada, asking him to visit the Reserve, ascertain the facts and report to me. On January 6th he wrote me a letter in which he assures me that the most that can be said against Brother Scott is that he has been indiscreet. He states that only upon two occasions in one week did he give the young woman referred to a ride in his car and that he had no wrong intention in the matter.

He says he discussed the whole matter with Mr. Emerson Snake, the Indian who made the report to Mr. Stone and says that Mr. Snake without full consideration advised Mr. Stone to write to me. When Mr. Snake returned home that day and after more careful consideration he wrote Mr. Stone to defer writing to me for the present, but Mr. Stone's letter was already on its way. When Mr. Stone intimated in his letter to me that he had not advised the Department of Indian Affairs in the matter, I wrote him stating that I appreciated his courtesy in writing me as he had done, but was not sure but that he ought to report the facts as he understood them to the Department at Ottawa. I appreciate the fact that Mr. Stone should have communicated with you before writing to me, but I presume that he did not think the matter as serious as the Indians made it out to be and thought it would be better not to give any publicity to it.

My personal judgment is that the Indians have been unduly suspicious and Mr. Stone has been guilty of nothing more than indiscretion, - if even that could be said about him, - and I think it would be well for the Department to allow him to remain at Moraviantown as I am quite sure he will be very careful in the future. Any report I have of him is to the effect that he is a very fine young man and I would be sorry to see any reflection cast upon his character. If I had any suspicion that he had been guilty of wrong doing I would ask for his resignation and nominate another man for the position which he holds, but under the circumstances I think it is just as well to let the matter drop.
A. P. MacKenzie, Esq.

If you concur in this judgment, I would be glad to have word from you to that effect.

I am,

Faithfully yours,

Dear Sir;-

RE MORAVIANTOWN.

Since writing you on January 11th in regard to affairs at Moraviantown, I have had a further recommendation from the Rev. Mr. Bartlett, who is Superintendent of that Mission.

He has been in further conference with Mr. Scott, the Missionary Teacher there, who had sent to me his resignation. He now advises that we accept that resignation, - not because he believes that Mr. Scott has been intentionally guilty of any wrong doing, but he thinks it would be better, in the interests of all concerned, if someone were to take Mr. Scott's place.

Will the Department consent to the Rev. C. W. MacKenzie, who is now Assistant Principal of Muncey Indian Residential School, taking charge at Moraviantown without delay? He is a graduate in Arts, taught school for three and one-half years in Ontario, and for one and one-half years in Alberta. He attended Normal School in the spring of 1915, but his health gave way just before examination time and he, consequently, did not write on the final examinations. He is, doubtless, pretty well known to your Department, and I have reason to believe that, if you would favor his appointment to Moraviantown, I could arrange with him to go there without delay.

Awaiting your reply, I am,

Very faithfully yours,

C. E. Manning

Moraviantown, Ont. July 26, 1899

The Honorable

The Superintendent of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa,

Sir: May I trouble you to consider the case of an Indian girl for whom something must be done. Sarah Jackson, an orphan, is the daughter of Charles Jackson, a Delaware from the Six Nations Reserve.

She was born in March 1875, and entered the Orphanage at Moraviantown in Dec., 1893. While here she seemed to do quite well both in her studies and in learning to work. A lady living near Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, U.S.A. being interested...
in our work, kindly offered to take her into her family, train her for usefulness, pay her wages and surround her with all the influences of a Christian home. She said: "I assure you I feel the responsibility fully. As far as I am given light, I will guard her and guide her. For love of the Master I will do all I can to keep her close to Him." To us it seemed an open door through which the girl might enter into a better life than exists on the Reserves, and she was sent to her new home in December, 1895.

After seven months of trial in two situations, she was sent back to this
Reserve... I enclosed please find a copy of the lady's letter stating why she could not keep the girl.

She at first refused to return to the orphanage, and wandered around from house to house, remaining out very late at night. Her uncle, with whom she had chosen to make her home, found it impossible to restrain her, and prevailed upon us to give her a shelter until something could be done with her. Her grandfather, John Peters, pleaded most earnestly with us not to return her to the Six Nations Reserve as those, in whose company she would fall, are not...
according to all reports, leading the right kind of lives. She would like, if possible, that she should be sent to some reformatory. On account of her conduct, the Superintendent of Mt Elgin Institution refuses to receive her. We can not keep her here. The only thing possible to prevent her from leading a dissolute life seems to be that she should be sent to some place like the Andrew Mercer School.

Would the Department of Indian Affairs assume the expense, and, if so, will you kindly authorize Mr. A. R. McDonald, agent for this Reserve, to take the necessary
steps for her commitment to that Institution.

If this can not be done, what shall we do with her? If she is not restrained there seems to be every probability of her growing worse and eventually through an evil life, becoming a burden to the community.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient Servant,

T.M. Rights
Dear Sir:

After seven months of trial with Sarah Jackson, I return her. She leaves here tomorrow morning. You will see by the enclosed letter, that Mrs. Renshaw also made an effort but she gave her up with only a few days trial, and tried to get in some house and was unable to do so.

I am very much surprised you sent her home after I wrote you should not take her unless she was honest truthful & obedient.

She could not develop the character that she is, suddenly, nor could she live five years in a place without being taken.

My only regret is I did not return her the first month she was here.

Yours truly,

Mrs. W. C. Wilson

Sir: I have the honor to report that the school and orphanage carried on for many years in connection with the mission work of the Moravian Church on the reserve of the Moravian Band of the Huron was discontinued at the close of the summer term in 1899.

There is a good public school on the Reserve taught by a normal school graduate Miss M. J. Smith. Three of the children who were in the orphanage were admitted as pupils of the Elgin Institution. The seven who remained were returned to their parents.

During the last few years the expenditure for the mission work of the church has largely exceeded the contributions.

The authorities of the church have decided that retrenchment must take place whenever it is at all possible.

I have the honor to be,

J. M. Wright

Sir:

With further reference to your letter of the 15th instant relative to the obtaining of the services of a teacher for the Moraviantown Indian Day School to succeed Mr. Knechtel, I have to inform you that the authorities of the United Church of Canada have nominated John Donald Scott as teacher for the next school year. Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing the Dec, Qr, Day School Return of my agency, Teacher—"Rev. C.W. McKenzie."

You will notice that I have not certified to this Return, and I will explain as to why.

I received a letter from Mr. McKenzie, dated Dec. 17/38, stating that he was sorry to report that he found it necessary to close down school owing to ill health, had not been able to do church work on Sunday, consequently school closed Dec. 14/38.

In his report you will see 3½ days closed for sickness before sending this to Dept., I wrote Mr. McKenzie stating that I could not certify to this report knowing that school was closed all of week;

He refuses to do this and states that he or his wife had rehearsals with children each afternoon in Hall in preparation for Xmas concert, and he considered this part of school curriculum.

I told Mr. McKenzie if this was the case he should have given full explanation in the column for remarks of school report.

Was afraid Dept. would or might later censure me if I certified to this School Return knowing these facts.

Mr. McKenzie now states I have accused him of making a false Return, I have on file copy of my letter to him which I will be only too glad to furnish to Dept. on request.

Will certify to Return when advised by Dept.

Yours Obediently,

Nelson Stone,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

Sir,

The Department wishes to have a garden cultivated in connection with the Moraviantown Indian school this summer, and I have to ask you to be good enough to at once consult with the teacher and make the necessary arrangements to have the land plowed and to purchase a few gardening tools and some seeds. Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find requisition sheet for lead pencils and erasers which I trust may be forwarded as soon as possible.

As to monthly reports, I did not send in one for January. Considering the rough cold weather the attendance for the past two months has been very fair and both parents and children show far more interest in the work. With moderated temperature the attendance became much better towards the end of February and is holding up well. I have had them out two Saturdays lately and they attended very well. Another Saturday will make up for the three days extra they had at Christmas and then they will have their full week at Easter. Those who attend regularly are doing well I am pleased to say.

Regarding the furnace I must say it is
poor affair in very weather. As it is only surrounded by a thin galvanized hot air pocket a large proportion of the heat is wasted in the basement. Were it bricked in I feel sure the school would be more easily heated and that there would be a great saving of fuel. I have had considerable experience with furnaces and have attended to it myself during the school hours. The janitor puts the fires on and the teacher does the work. Some days it was almost impossible to get the place warm before eleven and the children had to wear their overcoats. Such should not be the case. But the worst I trust is over for this winter.

Though the Department did not grant me a raise at Christmas I hope it may see fit to do so before Easter. I would not ask for it if I did not feel justified in so doing.

I remain respectfully yours

[Signature]

Without an examination of the Moravian town school furnace I am unable to say definitely what is the matter with the furnace. From the teacher's letter I should surmise that the fault is probably lack of proper attention, as he states in extreme that it is eleven o'clock before they can get the building warm. This would indicate that the fires are not maintained constantly, but allowed to go out at night and started in the morning and probably not much before school hour. It is hardly the fault of the furnace if the building can be heated by eleven o'clock, as it can be kept in the same condition at all times if proper attention is given; the fire being banked at night and replenished at an early hour in the morning, the outside cold air being shut off and the air in building only circulated while the school is unoccupied.

The furnace and pipes may also require cleaning as these have been in use for two seasons.

With respect to the casing of furnace, the galvanized iron cover is all that is considered necessary by manufacturers and round furnaces are seldom, if ever, bricked in.

The blackboard is inferior and is injurious to the children's eyes, which are naturally weak. A slate blackboard of best quality should extend all across the school room wall. REPORT OF INSPECTOR W.H. COLES ON THE MORAVIANTOWN SCHOOL.

The place is kept very untidy. Ashes and sweepings are strewn about the doors and on the steps. The basement is littered with chips and dirt.

The closets are not fit for children to use because they are not kept clean. The teacher seems to hold himself free from any blame, because the janitor is at fault.

Extract from report of Inspector W. H. G. Colles
on the Moraviantown Indian School dated May 31, 1918.
Original on 151868/6.

The heating system has been supplemented with
a stove in the school room. This should be removed.
A small gate should be put in between the
school ground and the garden plot. The fence has to be
climbed.

The school should be thoroughly cleaned and
disinfected at midsummer. The plaster walls should be
painted, a light tint being used.
Ottawa, June 8, 1918.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that Mr. Inspector Colles, in a recent report on the Moraviantown Indian School, states as follows:

"The heating system has been supplemented with a stove in the school-room. This should be removed.

"A small gate should be put in between the school ground and the garden plot. The fence has to be climbed.

"The school should be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected at midsummer. The plaster walls should be painted, a light tint being used."

You will be good enough to carry out the Inspector's suggestion and have the stove which is in the school-room removed and you are hereby authorized to have a small gate put in between the school ground and the garden plot.

During the summer holidays you should see that the school is thoroughly cleaned and disinfected and you may have the walls kalsomined, not painted.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

E. Beattie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Highgate, Ont.

SPECIFICATIONS FOR FURNACE INSTALLATION IN THE MORAVIAN SCHOOL, JULY 2, 1916.

Provide and fix in position required a coal or wood-burning hot air furnace of the Gurney Oxford pattern No. 2568, having a capacity of 30,000 to 40,000 cubic feet air with all appurtenances complete.

Furnace to be galvanized iron cased with cast-iron vapor pan, dust damper, check damper, etc., and to be so arranged that the draught may be controlled from school-room floor. The furnace to be installed in such position as to ensure thorough working of the apparatus and proper connections with the existing hot and cold air pipes, etc.

Should any of the pipes installed be in a damaged condition, these to be made good and the plant left at completion in a thorough and complete condition.

A written guarantee to heat the building to a temperature of 70 degrees Farh. at 10 below zero outside to be given by the Contractor before final payment is made.

2. The payments shall be made in cash in thirty days from date of installation. January 1st, 1918

Some things that should be looked after, which if not in good shape have a very telling effect.

One is, the Ceiling in the school is matched lumber, and if this is only a single matched ceiling with no under boarding or paper between it, it is very hard to keep heat in the Building.

There are also Luvar Windows, that is Slated Windows in pediments, to the attic. If all the above conditions are in good order so as to make the ceiling and attic wind-proof, a smaller sized furnace could be used, which would cost - Twenty dollars less.
