SPECIFICATIONS FOR FURNACE INSTALLATION IN THE MORAVIAN SCHOOL, JULY 2, 1916.

Provide and fix in position required a coal or wood-burning hot air furnace of the Gurney Oxford pattern No. 2565, having a capacity of 30,000 to 40,000 cubic feet air with all appurtenances complete.

Furnace to be galvanized iron cased with cast-iron vapor pan, dust damper, check damper, etc., and to be so arranged that the draught may be controlled from school-room floor. The furnace to be installed in such position as to ensure thorough working of the apparatus and proper connections with the existing hot and cold air pipes, etc.

Should any of the pipes installed be in a damaged condition, these to be made good and the plant left at completion in a thorough and complete condition.

A written guarantee to heat the building to a temperature of 70 degrees Farn. at 10 below zero outside to be given by the Contractor before final payment is made.

The attached memorandum requests the approval of His Excellency in Council of a contract for the erection of a residence for the teacher of the Indian day school on the Moravian reserve, and the purchase of a site from a member of the band.

There is no residence for the teacher of this school, and a resolution of the band sets forth the difficulty of retaining the services of teachers, as they cannot obtain satisfactory board and lodging.

The whole expenditure of $1250.00 would be charged to band capital (which amounts to $111,178.99) and is a reasonable one.

Recently tenders were invited from the Wallace Company, of Thamesville, and the Colin Reid Company, the former firm did not put in a tender, and the inclosed was received from the Colin Reid Company.

As a site for the residence, it was considered advisable to acquire three-quarters of an acre of land, adjoining the school grounds, and which is the property of a member of the band. The cost of this piece of ground is $100.00.

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

OTTAWA, May 25th, 1921.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a report from Mr. Colles, Inspector of Public Schools, on his recent visit to the Moraviantown Indian Day School, in which he states that the stair railing at the east entrance is rotten and in bad condition and needs repairing, also that the boy's closet and the fence between the closets need repairing. He also states that the school room and furniture need a good washing.

I have, therefore, to request that you will make the necessary arrangements to have the stair railing repaired, repairs made to the boy's closet and fence, and the school room and furniture thoroughly scrubbed and washed. All of the above work should be done at the lowest possible expenditure, and you should furnish properly receipted vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

Regarding the school garden; the Department desires that it be continued this season. The Inspector states that the Council instructed the teacher not to carry on this work this Spring. The Council have no authority in this matter, and I have to request that you will be good enough to consult the teacher as to the seed required for the purpose of planting the garden, and arrange for the purchase and delivery of same, as soon as possible, in order that the work can be completed before the season is too far advanced. It is considered that gardening is an important factor in the education of Indian children, and it is hoped that it is not too late to have the work performed and the garden planted.

The Inspector also states that a new truant office is being appointed, and it is hoped that he will carry out his duties more proficiently than his predecessor, and that he will see that all the children of school age, and who are in good health, will attend regularly.

The Inspector also states that there is a quantity of school supplies required, as well as a few other articles, and the teacher should prepare a requisition and forward it to your office for the supplies required.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

E. Beattie, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Highgate, Ont.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir,

I wish to write you in reference to a recent visit made to our school (Moraviantown) by the inspector, Mr. Colles of Chatham. He was considerably incensed over a change that had been made in the position of the closets, and insisted that they would have to be moved back again to where they were before.

The arrangements had been made for the change, by the Chief Council and Agent, about the time I came here last fall, and they tell me that the reason for making the change was that the closets were so close together that communications were too easily passed from the one to the other, and that children in the one were frequently annoyed by those of the other sex.

I am told by those who have lived here ever since the school was built, that the closets were originally much farther apart, and admitted of no possible intercourse from the one to the other; and that it was the inspector's suggestion that they be placed near together in the rear of the school building. If this is the case it helps to explain why he is so annoyed at the position being altered.

If your Dept. is asked to have the closets put back where they were, will you please consider the reasons given above for their removal before authorizing any further change.

Yours sincerely,

Frank J. Joblin.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

CHATHAM, ONT. March 12th, 1923.

Dear Sir:

I have just had a note from Rev. Mr. Joblin, a teacher at the Moravian Indian school. You will remember at the teacher's residence, we put on an addition to the school under which a basement was constructed. The building of a cistern, water-pipes, sink, etc., was not part of the contract of the Reid Company of Bothwell who built the building. It was my intention to make application to the Department for permission to put this in together with a drain suitable for carrying the water away from the waste-pipe but I did not do this as I learned from Mr. Beatty that he had made application to the department for the cistern, sink, etc. Mr. Beatty called for tenders and awarded the contract to the Lambert Company of Highgate. The excavation for the cistern was made last and the cistern which is a very flimsy granite, iron affair, was brought out. Since that time nothing has been done.

I believe the contract also included putting on eave troughs. Mr. Joblin states that the excavation of the cistern is now filled up with water and that his cellar is becoming flooded. As the case seemed urgent, I called up Mr. Lambert on the telephone and he stated that he would complete his contract as soon as possible. He stated that his contract did not include putting in a drain to drain the waste water from the sink away. I immediately got in touch with Mr. Beatty and instructed him to have a drain put in to carry the water away as if it was not done immediately the contents of Mr. Joblin's cellar would be ruined.

Yours truly,

R. H. Abraham,
Agr. Rep. Dept. Ind. Aff.

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Sec. Dept. Ind. Aff.
Ottawa.

Ottawa, May 1st, 1923.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Moraviantown Indian Day School, recommends that the teacher be supplied with fruit trees and small fruit bushes to plant out and make a permanent garden.

I may say that we do not furnish supplies of this nature to Indian day schools, but there may be good reasons why the Inspector's recommendations should be carried out in the case of the Moraviantown school. I shall, therefore, be pleased to have your views as to whether you would recommend that a number of fruit trees and small fruit bushes be supplied. The list as recommended by the Inspector is as follows:

- 2 Doz. black currant bushes (Boscoor Giant),
- ½ " apple trees - 2 Snow apple, 2 Harvent apple,
- 2 Northern Spy,
- 2 pear trees - Duchess, Oldenburg, 1 Kiefer,
- ½ Doz. roots rhubarb,
- 4 Doz. raspberry bushes,
- 100 strawberry plants,
- 3 grape vines - Concord,
- 2 plum trees - 1 Lombardy, 1 Green Gage,
- 6 peach trees - 3 Early Crawford, 3 Late Crawford.

A question to be considered is, who would care for these trees especially during the summer holidays when the teacher is likely to be absent. The approximate cost should be stated.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

The means for washing hands are not available. No stands for basins, no towels or soap where children can use them.

Sir,

The Separate School inspector in a report on his recent inspection of the Moraviantown Indian Day School, states that there are no means provided for the washing of the children's hands and recommends that stands for basins, towels and soap be provided.

You may arrange for the purchase of two wash basins, six yards of roller towelling, twelve cakes of toilet soap and two stands for the basins. No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred and the above should be placed in charge of the teacher for use by the pupils as required.

The inspector states that while there is a school flag and pole, the necessary cord and pully #3 required. You may purchase this equipment and arrange to have it installed on the flag pole.

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the above equipment.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

In reply to letter No. I5-I-5 dated May 12th, 1924, I would state that Mr. Colles, Public School Inspector for Kent County, made this same report of Moravian Day School some two years ago. And you then instructed my predecessor, (Mr. Beattie) as you are instructing me now. Beattie purchased Toweelling, basins, soap and then proceeded to investigate. He found there was no possible place to install this toilet equipment, and further, Mr. Colles has not been successful in having persuaded any Public School Board in his district to install his pet toilet system.

The very day I received your letter, I was to reserve with R.H. Abraham, and he, Frank J. Joblin (Teacher) and I talked this matter over, and we were all agreed that it would be out of the question to find any place in the school building to install this equipment without it being in the road and a nuisance. Mr. Colles was for a great many years an efficient officer of the Educational Department. But, and I am sorry to have to say it, Colles is in his dotage, and there is not one School Board in his district that any of his reports or recommendations seriously.
Ottawa, May 20th, 1924.

Sir,

I am enclosing Dec. Qr. Report of Moravian Day School, Teacher, Earl A. Knechtel, B.A.

I think Mr. Knechtel is doing splendid work, and is liked by both pupils and parents. I think the pupils are making good progress. I notice that the School premises and the pupils themselves appear to be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. I was out to School yesterday to the closing exercises. The teacher had arranged for a little program, a goodly number of parents were present and I can assure you that the manner in which each item or number of this program was rendered reflected credit on both teacher and pupils. I took a little treat out for everybody and it yielded to me a great deal of pleasure to see the way it was appreciated by all present. I wish to inform the Dept. that I have not yet installed the Wash-stands, basins, soap, towels &c. in the School. I took the matter up with the teacher and we cannot devise at present any place for them, the entry or cloak room on each side as very small not proper room for coats, hats and dinner pails, and if they were installed in this entry, the water would freeze in winter very quickly. There is a small room at the back of school room, unused, that with a little expense could be made...
useful for the above purpose, but any of these entry rooms are not provided with any heat from the present system of heating. In the summertime I think the proper place for the wash-basins is outside and the towels should be just inside the entry. I have had the 6 window shades installed but not the clock. The teacher requested me to wait a little before getting it, as he is not real sure at present as to it being a benefit in the School.

Next Spring I will see if it is not possible to make some adjustments or alterations in rear of this building, so that this unused portion may be utilized. If I conclude it can be done, I will get an estimate on the cost, take the matter up with Chief and Council and if they are agreeable, I will then submit it to The Department for their consideration.

Yours Obediently,

Nelson Stone,

Moved, voted and carried that Agent ask Dept. to approve of installing a large heating box stove in school house before close of winter to see if the stove burning wood, would not be more economical and satisfactory than coal in the furnace in the basement.

I think we can get a second-hand stove on approval but we would have to get about $15.00 worth of stove pipe to install this plan for experiment, of course if the scheme proved O.K. the pipe would be utilized permanently and I think we could purchase the stove for about $25.00 or less. Last year we paid for coal alone $216.41 and around $50.00 for wood for school house. Now if this new plan can be operated successfully, I think this building could be well heated for a lot less money, and the fuel all purchased from the Indians and the permits for sale that we are at present issuing could be absorbed on the reserve and in this way serve a double purpose, as the reserve would be receiving all the benefit from its products. You can understand that a coal fire must be a perpetual thing during night and day of each school week during cold weather, whereas a wood fire in school house could be started at 7.30 O'clock A.M. and be discontinued at 3.30 P.M. and if properly looked after during that period, the building should be well heated during school hours and in this way considerable fuel conserved. I honestly think the plan, viewed from different angles is worth trying out.

Yours obediently,

(Sgd.) Nelson Stone.
Ottawa, February 7, 1925.

Sir:

With reference to the minutes of the meeting of the Moravian Council relative to the installing of a large box stove in the school building to be used for heating purposes in place of the present furnace, I beg to say that the Department will, in view of the request of the Band and your recommendation regarding same, approve of a wood burning stove of the size and type considered suitable being purchased and installed. You may also purchase the supply of stove pipe required. We note it is considered that if this change in heating the building can be successfully operated that a considerable sum will be saved in the purchase of fuel. You may, therefore, arrange for the purchase and installation of the stove as soon as possible, and give it a trial as to whether it will be suitable for heating the building or not.

No unnecessary expense should be incurred in the purchase of the stove and stove pipe, and you should forward properly certified vouchers covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

AGENTS REPORT OF THE MARCH 1925 MEETING OF THE MORAVIAN COUNCIL.

Moved, voted and carried that we purchase 20 cords of 18" wood for school at $3.25 - 15 cords of 14" wood for Teachers residence at $3.00 - 3 cords of 36" wood for Council Hall at $4.00

This would be for next fall and winter. I also took the Council over to school and we find after consulting with teacher, that it would not be wise to install a stove in school room, as at present the school attendance is increasing and all the space is required for seating capacity, but the furnace is badly in need of immediate repairs and I am arranging to have this done on Saturday and I think it would be wise to try wood in this furnace and if it is successful, which I believe it will be, then we would not need to purchase any more coal, but burn all wood in these public buildings, and the outlay for fuel would be all expended on the reserve. If the wood is not a success in this furnace, then I would suggest installing a pipeless furnace in basement.

Nelson Stone.
Agent.
Ottawa, March 6th, 1925.

Sir:

With reference to the resolution of the Moravian Council regarding the fuel required for the use of the Moraviantown Indian Day School and teacher's residence, as well as for the council hall, I beg to say that the Department will approve of the quantity required for next winter's use being obtained. You will be good enough to see that the full quantity of wood as mentioned in the resolution is delivered in each case. You should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred for each service separately.

We note that you do not consider it would be advantageous to install a stove in the schoolroom, as, owing to the increased attendance, all space is required for seating purposes. You should have the furnace repaired and placed in a satisfactory condition. We note you consider that wood could be satisfactorily used in all the public buildings on the reserve, and that it would not be necessary to obtain coal. After a trial of wood in the furnace at the school, you should report as to whether it has been found satisfactory or whether it will be necessary to obtain coal for next winter's use.

And after making this inspection I find there is considerable of the plaster on inside that should be taken off as it is quite loose, also after making a thorough inspection of the outside woodwork, I have concluded that considerable repairs are needed to outside and two coats of paint should be given to all wood work on the outside;

The old paint is entirely off in many parts of outside, and the wood will very soon decay if left in this condition.

Would strongly recommend having this work all done during summer vacation;

Can get all inside work done, which includes plastering and two coats of paint for $90.00

Can get outside painting and carpenter work done for $85.00

This includes labor and material in both cases.

Think Council would approve of same, as the work will be well done, and is much needed, and the price very reasonable.

Please advise me promptly as it will require all the balance of the vacation to complete this work and have it ready by opening of school.

Yours Obediently,

Nelson Stone, Agent for Moravians.

Highgate, Ont.

Ottawa, July 21, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, with reference to the repairs required to the Moraviantown Indian Day School building and furnishing an estimate of their cost.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange to have the plaster on the inside repaired and any necessary repairs made to the outside of the building. All outside woodwork should be given two coats of paint. It is noted that you estimate the cost of having all inside work required, including plastering and two coats of paint, to be $90 and that the outside painting and carpenter work would cost approximately $85, these amounts to include labour and material. Please have all this work carried out before the school re-opens after the present summer holidays. You may arrange for the purchase of all material required, after obtaining competitive prices, and for the labour, or you may give the work to a contractor - he to supply all material and labour. However, you should see that a good grade of paint, etc., is used.

After the work is completed, you should forward a properly certified voucher, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred. The Department will expect you to see that all work is completed to your satisfaction.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Nelson Stone, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Highgate, Ont.

"Please supply 2 wash basins, soap and towels, and a mirror. We should have a few good pictures hung up. A common work-table, 2½ ft. x 4 ft. is needed for the Primer and Kindergarten work, and a supply of kindergarten materials.

"We need in the window frames, 8 inch wide, deflectors to prevent direct draft when the sashes are raised (Mr. Scott's idea and all right).

"The closets are old, cheaply made and unsanitary in principle. These closets should not have been removed out into the play-grounds.

"This is a handsome upstanding brick building on an excellent site, well planted with trees. There are few schools better than this.

"I desire to thank the Department for their ready compliance with requests for improvements.

"One feature that needs correction, under supervision, is the outdoor closets. These should be replaced by Kaustine closets."
Ottawa, October 10, 1927.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Moraviantown Indian Day School, recommends that the following supplies be furnished for the use of the school, and you may arrange for the purchase of same:

- 2 Wash Basins
- 6 Yds. Towelling,
- 12 Cakes Soap (Toilet),
- 1 Inexpensive Mirror.

The Inspector also states that a common work table, 2½' x 4', is required for the primer and kindergarten work. It is thought that you can arrange to have a suitable table made locally that would be satisfactory for the purpose, or you may arrange for the purchase of same.

The Inspector further states that a supply of kindergarten material is required. Please have the teacher make out a requisition for the supplies of this nature considered necessary.

The Inspector also states that there is needed in each window a deflector, 5" wide, to prevent direct draught when the sashes are raised. Please consult the teacher regarding this matter, and ascertain the cost of same, and inform the Department.

The Inspector also states that the closets are old, cheaply made and unsanitary, and that they should not have been removed out into the playgrounds. I shall be pleased to have a report from you regarding the closets and what you would recommend be done to overcome the difficulty mentioned by the Inspector.

Please give an estimate of the cost of any work you would recommend be done.

Your obedient servant,

Nelson Stone, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Highgate, Ont.

Dear Sirs,

Replying to Dept. Letter No. I5-I-5 of the 10th inst., in reference to a report made by the Public School Inspector and his recommendation for purchase of various equipment, repairs etc., to school house and outbuildings; I would say that his recommendation is to a great degree impractical.

He has time and time again suggested installing wash basins, soap towels etc., and I defy him to show me any place or spare room to place them.

He recommended some few years before my time as agent, a table the same as in this report to be purchased; it was purchased and never used by any teacher, discarded and no teacher in my time ever wished to have one, but now the present teacher asks for it and the Inspector recommends it.

He recommends a deflector 8" wide for the bottom of each window, this glass would have to be attached to both sides of frame, would be unprotected and I venture to say broken frequently, would cost at least $30.00 to install and have never yet noticed a similar device in any school of County.

The Inspector recommended in a recent report to have Closets repaired, I arranged to have them repaired as instructed to by Dept. Now he states they should not have been removed out into playgrounds; They were erected where they are at present, and no better place could be chosen for them, at the back of grounds right against the fence out of the road of playgrounds; The Well is at the front and surely he does not wish closets placed adjacent to well.

The Dept. can judge for themselves, but I do know that No School Board of the County of Kent takes any report of Mr. Colles seriously.

Yours Obediently,

Nelson Stone,
Agent for Moravians.
